and then we have funny stuff like MMP, which aims at fair party representation and local representatives simultaneously. Each voter has two votes, one for a candidate (FPTP within the constituency) and the other for a party (which are proportional on a national level) Every candidate that got their majority goes to parliament and the proportional votes ensure that parliament is put together as closely as possible to which party the people voted for. Only issue is that due to rounding additional seats might be necessary.
And since it is rather rare to get an absolute majority for a single party, coalitions are formed and half a dozen parties are staying successful.

The problem with voting isn't really how we vote representatives, but rather that we vote representatives at all. No system in which you vote representatives will not screw over large parts of the population, including the people that voted them. We get one vote to decide on at least a few hundred issues, it's impossible to make any real decisions that way. Campaign promises aren't binding in any way, politicians can freely ignore the opinion of the voters without having to worry about anything other than the next election. No matter which party you vote for or why, chances are, you'll get screwed over. What we should be voting on is the actual issues, not politicians that can freely screw us over for their own benefit without having to fear consequences. That way countries wouldn't split as much into camps and blindly accuse the other camp while defending their own either. There'd still be divisive issues, sure, but at least people would have some common grounds instead of being pitted against each other while politicians and companies fill their own pockets. Maybe voting on every little thing would be too difficult, but setting a certain course for various major issues should be the baseline for what can be considered a democracy, not this illusion of choice we have.

I don't agree with the conclusion:

In Approval voting, every voter will eventually only vote for their one favourite party, if the party has a chance at winning. They will only vote for other parties if they are about to lose and want to minimize the chance that the party they dislike wins.

Therefore, it will basically degrade into plurality voting anyway.

Even worse, all but the least favorite party with power will basically merge into one big counter-party, which then gives a lot of power to the political extremes.

So, eventually it degrades into a plurality voting, BUT with parties even less representative of the population.

Instant runoff does work, but has its weaknesses as you explained.

The best way to improve voting is, if you just don't make a voting system with a single winner.

In Switzerland, there is no single president. The executive branche of the government consists of 7 people.

Since it's not a "the winner takes it all" system, no party or person has any reason to vote strategically, because they don't want to win, they want a bigger piece of the cake.

And I make completely opposite conclusion: plurality system with strategic voting (two party system) is the best. It is the voter who decides to compromise, with zero chance of shenanigans by the voter system. The party candidates over time will shift positions to satisfy the maximum amount of the voters (or they will be outplayed by another party).

other voting methods

instant runoff but instead of dropping the candidate with the least number of first preferences you drop the candidate with the most number of last preferences. the idea behind this is you can get a candidate that gets very few first preferences but is everyone's second preference vs a candidate that most people really hate. the argument is that it's more democratic to remove the most hated candidates before you remove the candidates that a lot of people like but just don't like enough to put down as first preference. and yes this version of instant runoff does often result in a different candidate winning the election

Condorcet voting
candidates are put against each other 1v1. so in this example, you would vote 3 times. 1st orange vs green, then purple vs green then purple vs orange. Whoever wins the most 1v1 matchups is the winner. Condorcet is regarded mathematically speaking as the most democratic system. however it is possible to get a rock paper scissors scenario where orange is more popular than green, green is more popular than purple but purple is more popular than orange and there's no winner. because of that rock paper scissor problem that can come up it's not very popular despite it being the most democratic system

borda count
like range voting where different candidates get a different amount of points except you can't pick which how many points go to which candidates. in this example your first pick gets 2 points, your second pick gets 1 point your 3rd pick gets no points. it avoids the chicken dilemma but it can result in candidates that neither runoff nor Condorcet would've elected.

For example one reasonable model of this I think would be to assume over a population, on average, betrayal would occur when the distance between the blob and it's 2nd favourite candidate is more than double the distance between the blob and it's first favourite candidate.

I think you could take that a step further by incorporating that, even if that condition is met betrayal won't happen if another candidate is very far from the blob. i.e. if a blob's first choice is 1 measure away, and 2nd choice is 3 measures away, and 3rd choice is 4 measures away. Then rather than voting 1 & 2 they will betray 2. But if the 3rd choice instead of being 4 measures away is 1000 measures away (say their policy is they want to painfully murder everyone on the planet), then in that instance the blob will care more about that choice not winning so won't betray their 2nd choice and will vote 1&2. I think this model would be a reasonable approximation of reality, and unlikely the other strategic voting shown being a reason not to use the system, I think in this case it would be a good thing?

I think IRV potentially has additional benefits where the results of all rounds are published it at least gives more information what voters really prefer. In theory this could encourage the losing parties to compromise in order to better represent and thus attract the support of more voters. If you are the runner up then then there is a learning exercise in looking into what positions of the third place candidate are palatable to you? The goal of course being to make concessions in order to attract the support of some of those that shifted to your opponent as their backup choice without sacrificing your existing supporters. I would argue the perceived problems with approval voting are actually benefits:

In the case of a voter choosing not to approve all candidates when they could honestly approve all of them, I don't see the problem. In an ideal world, every voter would face this dilemma: everyone would find every candidate acceptable, and if everyone voted "honestly" you'd get a massive tie. So for this election to mean anything, voters would have to express their preferences. Someone could also argue voters who don't like any option are being "dishonest" by putting any mark on their ballot; but that's obviously silly. So it is a good thing that every voter has the opportunity to express some degree of preference.

In the case of the chicken dilemma, the way a particular ballot impacts the election results is extremely transparent. A vote for a candidate always helps them, and not voting for a candidate always hurts them. So if a voter chooses to betray their second favorite candidate, it is because from their perspective the reward of getting their favorite outweighs the risk of getting their least favorite candidate. If they lose this bet, the voter at least understands why they got the outcome they did. And based on the real-world results of iterated prisoner's dilemma problems (because that is what this problem simplifies as), we can expect in the long term voters will learn cooperation is the better strategy. Don't we want a system that rewards cooperation, and punishes division?

Now let's take these to their logical conclusion over time.

Once the number of candidates in a pluralist system passes a threshold, the beliefs of those candidates become arbitrary with the caveat that any set of majority parties will be diametrically opposed. That is to say, eventually it won't matter what anyone in these parties believes, because it's not about what they believe it's about what the other person believes and denying that. This is without a doubt, the current election meta in America.

In the case of Instant Runoff, over time, the government will be based around the most extremist policies as all the moderate candidates are eliminated. Considering that the Australian flag was flown in the US Capitol Riots and Australia continues to implement weird policies like consistently banning objectionable video games, I'd say there's evidence for that there too.

And in an approval based system, the status quo becomes god, since the least controversial candidate will always win (assuming a great enough number of candidates). This might sound nice, but remember that in many places, child marriage is the status quo and banning it would be seen as controversial. No country has fully implemented an Approval based system, so there's no evidence that I'm right other than conjecture, so take it with a grain of salt.

Plurality is bad if you consider one candidate as a winner.
But it's not if you consider a representative assembly (like in a parliament), because they can agree on certain subjects with each other.

For example: Green got the most votes overall. But if asked "apples or mangos", then orange and purple would outweigh green.

One benefit of plurality voting (or negative depending on your views) is that while two parties will always be the norm, the two parties have to actively work to negate the spoiler effect. IE undercut third parties. This is terrible for people who want multiple parties that better represent their views….but it’s actually pretty good at moderating the two largest parties. Because to undercut third parties, the main parties will often adopt positions from similar parties, though generally in a less radical form so they don’t lose their base. This is why the democrats in the US have such a wide range of politicians who, in any other system, would never be under the same banner. IE AOC and Nancy Pelosi really shouldn’t be in the same party, but since they’re ideologically closer to each other than to the republicans, they moderate or radicalize their own positions to something both of their voters can tolerate. And while leftists will hate that people like AOC have to moderate themselves, the far right members of the Republican Party have the same issue, namely that to retain a spot in the winning coalition, they need to moderate themselves.

Now obviously this isn’t always true, and there are layers to this, such as the fact that radical elements tend to drag the larger parties closer to where they’d prefer to be (like how far right elements have essentially taken over the republicans, or how far left elements have pushed the democratic agenda farther left), but on the whole, I’d say this moderation element is at least part of why the US has done much better at mitigating far right nationalism than some other countries.

…of course this is also partially why the US social progression has occurred at a snail’s pace, but I feel like if the benefits and negatives of all the voting systems are being discussed, it’s important to talk about this one.

FPTP fails on both counts if there are more than two candidates.
IRV works extremely well in regards to positive voting, but can on occasion fail in regards to negative voting.
And approval voting utterly fails in regards to positive voting, but works well for negative voting.

Between the three, IRV is clearly the best. There's no real question, approval's too prone to turning into FPTP. But approval is the second best.

One thing that's worth noting is that approval and IRV aren't mutually exclusive. You can, conceivably, make a system that allows you to rank the candidates from best to worst, and let people rank candidates on the same level.

If there is a single way in which doing so isn't clearly superior to both IRV and approval, I've yet to see it. It takes the positive voting element from IRV and the negative voting element from approval and puts them together, so that you can always vote in favor of the candidate you want to win whilst voting against the worst case scenario.

But you can combine the weaknesses to essentially revert it to IRV, which is notably imperfect. Still very good, but not the best.

However, we do have the ability to go even further... Beyond....
And that's to make a tier list.
You give every candidate a tier, and a rank within that tier. Your vote goes to every candidate within the top remaining tier until only one tier remains, then it switches to IRV for the remaining candidates.
With a system like that, you will always have the ability to ensure that you're voting against the worst case scenario candidate, but at the same time you'll have no conceivable reason to avoid voting for anyone for fear of them beating your preferred choice.
It is, as far as I can thusfar see, flawless.

'Course, I'd be interested to see what I've yet to.

The reason plurality voting is called "first past the post" voting is because there's no victory threshold. The only threshold is doing better than the other competitors.

Now you might be thinking, "Isn't that just how ALL horse races work?" but it wasn't always that way. Back in the day, some horse races (especially very long ones) had time thresholds in addition to placement bets. That is, instead of betting that Horse #4 comes in first (or in the top two or three), you could bet that Horse #4 comes in first AND under a certain, specified time. There would be a slightly longer time thresholds built into place (top two) and show (top three) bets. You would only win these bet if your horse not only won, placed, or showed, but did so within the time allotted.

A "first past the post" race, however, has no time threshold. Whichever horse wins, bettors on that horse get paid no matter how long is actually takes for that horse to come in first. You're not betting against a minimum threshold - you're betting only against the other horses . . . just like how, under plurality voting, it doesn't matter how many votes you get, so long as it's more than your competitors.

The fundamental flaw with the plurality system has to do with human psychology. We are creatures of habit, lovers of the status quo; therefore, we tend to stick with the familiar, even when the unfamiliar would be objectively more beneficial. That's why independent parties can't really take hold; human psychology goes, "You know, this guy from this other party brings up some really valid points, and I kinda agree with most of what they're saying... but noooooo ima scaaaaared comfort zone comfort zone comfort zone." It's really why nothing ever really changes: because deep down, we don't want change. We want comfort in familiarity. Change only happens when familiarity becomes so actively harmful as to render change absolutely necessary.

I wonder how approval would work if you ranked the candidates 0 to x, where x is the number of voters minus 1. So, for example, with 3 candidates, you ranked them 0 to 2, with 0 being who you liked the least & 2 (or x) being your favorite. That way, people can be honest & not have to worry about betraying the other candidate. Although, the downside I see right away is if you're forcing voters to only assign a single number once, this will either force voters to learn about candidates they aren't interested in or vote a number randomly for those they don't know or care about, especially once you get up to a higher number of candidates. Like, I can imagine that most people who are interesred in voting have their most favorite & 2nd most favorite, along with their absolute least favorite, but they only covers 3 candidates. 4 wouldn't be hard for them, and 5 wouldn't affect the polls too much, but once you get into 7, 8, 9, or even 10 candidates, you'd then have people not knowing who to put in 7 different spots, and when scoring from 0 to 9, the difference between a score of 1 and a score of 7 is huge.

You determine "good" from "bad" on a very narrow window here, which is my primary complaint with videos trying to cover these other systems. FPTP has the benefit in that you can't really gamify the system like you can the others. It also keeps infighting between parties down and sets up clearly defined lines of politicraft. It's very hard to broker a political battle on multiple fronts and it's hard to build allies when only some of your political beliefs align. This ultimately leads to the rise of Centrism, or what I like to call rulership of the lazy greys. Very little ever seems to get accomplished under this kind of system because outside of the extremely banal or the occasional existential issues, most groups end up not being able to build up enough political will to enact new policy effectively.

There's also the issue of paralysis of choice. If I have two candidates that I like, but for different reasons, I'm going to have a hard time choosing between them. In a polarized system this rarely occurs, but in a Majoritarian or Runoff election this pops up all over and ends up causing people to think strategically and intentionally gamify the system. As South Park pointed out though picking between two unpallatable candidates is not very fun, however that's where the primary system comes into play. More on that in a minute.

Finally there's the minority rule problem. We already have people complaining about close elections even when it's between two candidates or a political dichotomy. Take Brexit for example. Those who opposed Brexit complain that 48% don't want it and so they shouldn't have to endure the realities of that election because they claim it's not fair that a slim majority can dictate to them and upset the status quo in such a significant way. Well think about what would happen if only 34% voted Brexit and 33% voted stay, and 33% voted renegotiate (or some other 3rd stance). Now you have 66% who voted against Brexit effectively, and they're mad. When a majority of the people feel like they're being ruled by a minority that doesn't represent them, even if they technically constitute a plurality of voters, bad things end up happening, just ask the French.

In reality the American election system is a hybrid of runoff (primary) and FPTP (general) elections, which is why it and other forms of elections have endured for so long despite your opinion that there are other "better" forms of elections available.

FPTP has several advantages in that it helps people set priorities, focus resources and the people do not suffer from paralysis of choice, which makes this "bad" system the one that most every democratic country adopts.

Approval voting also has the issue of strategically approving a blob that you don't actually approve of in order to sabotage the chances of a party that you approve of even less.

Take an example. We move orange between purple and green. We also have a very polarized voting environment such that most voters feel very strongly on some issue which divides purple and green. Green wants to put pineapple on pizza, but purple does not. There are therefore not many blobs in the center. Consequently, yellow would normally lose. However, if one or both sides believe that they may lose, voters may strategically approve of yellow, trying to prevent the other side from winning by giving the win to yellow who is naturally supported by a smaller voter base. This may result with a winner that few voters actually like.

Interesting, but these are only majoritarian systems as far as I am concerned. You didn't mention closed party list, parliamentarian democracies with proportional voting systems. Might be a very dumb system in an American context due to the huge diversity of the country,'s interests, though, making the US hard or impossible to govern. I find majoritarian democracies from the standpoint of representativeness and not as much from the standpoint of effective governance, to be excluding of so many of its citizens. All the flaws with the systems you described are related to this being majoritarian voting systems. While they have their upsides, majoritarian systems aren't designed for being representative - I wouldn't say it's a key feature of majoritarianism. That's my honest opinion.

EDIT: Btw, I don't agree that the plurality system is "just bad". It depends on from what criteria you judge it. It is a terrible system from the standpoint of representativeness, but so is instant runoff. Australia, as you showed, basically has a two-party system. If you value representativeness of the entirety of the population, a critique of it is legit. If you value it from the standpoint of accountability, not so much. Usually parliamentary seats in a plurality systems are based off of local districts. An MP who wants to keep his/her spot has to convince the local constituents that he/she is representing their interests well, otherwise they are going to punish the MP by simply not re-electing them. Another positive side of plurality that I can think of is effective governance. America would be a clusterfuck to govern if it didn't sacrifice some representativeness, going back to the reasoning above that you only included majoritarian systems in this video (since none of the 3 systems is perfectly representative). There are different models of democracy, and while I personally prefer a system of democracy to be representative, it might just not work well as a key principle in some institutional contexts.

Summary:

Plurality voting (a.k.a., first past the post). Every voter votes for exactly one candidate and the candidate with the most votes wins.
Flaw: Candidates with similar ideologies will be less successful than an ideologically isolated candidate/opponent because the vote count between ideologically similar candidates will be split (i.e., the spoiler effect).

Instant runoff voting (a.k.a., ranked-choice). Every voter ranks all the candidates from best to worst. The votes from the unsuccessful candidates are given to the voters’ second choice.
Flaw: centrist candidates are often unsuccessful when right-wing and left-wing candidates get more voters despite having the average opinion of the population (i.e., the center-squeeze phenomenon).
Positive effect: Because every voter must understand each candidate sufficiently, voters will likely make wiser decisions and vote only if they understand politics.

Approval voting. Every voter votes for all the candidates of whom they approve (as many or as few as they want).
Flaw: If voters only vote for their favourite candidate instead of all the candidates of which they approve, the spoiler effect can occur in this system as well (i.e., the chicken dilemma).

We take the average of the distances between a candidate and all of the voters.
We repeat this step for all candidates.
Winning condition: have the least average distance of all the candidates.

Some thoughts:
A distance along one axis represents how much Bob the blob (voter) agrees with Beany the greeny's (candidate) stand in that question.
If you take two questions (as in the video) you would get a two axis plane if you wanted to represent it.
While adding a third question would be easy, adding a fourt could be represented in either a.) a 3d space and a 1d line or b.) 4 1d lines.
By increasing the number of questions (1d lines or "axi") you can further improve the precision of the system in assigning each Bob the almost best possible Beany.
One more thing to consider is assigning the axi weights, so as to give Bob the chance to express which question he finds the most important.

A pragmatic point worth mentioning:
Voting needs to be easy, simple accessible at the polling place. It needs to account for those who cannot (eg due to learning disability) or will not (due to laziness, pomposity, stupidity) understand the rules and requirements of the process of casting a vaild vote.

This is where Approval voting is overwhelmingly favoured when compared Instant Runoff and many of the other scoring and proportional representation systems.
The advantage of Approval voting is that its worst failure mode is that it is treated by those who are too 'distracted' as the familiar one-man-one-vote, first-past-the-post plurality system that everyone is used to.
The next worst is that some will vote for every candidate, thus making no actual choice. This may reflect the voters genuine opinion (whether over-optimistic or nihilist) or be a non-vote by someone whose decision-making powers are called into question by this act (The voter themselves will be satisfied that they have exercised their franchise and their vote will be counted.
The Approval Vote can be more inclusive in examining spoilt ballots - fewer need be discarded and, though a voter may be record an additional unintended vote, at least their favoured candidate gets a vote counted, while particularly disfavoured candidates will only have an equal chance as neutral candidates of receiving an unintended vote - a net gain for the intention of the voter over the alternative of becoming disenfranchised.

On the downside, Approval voting is more susceptible to cheating with paper ballots or voter-verified machine ballots (unverified machine ballots are already too susceptible) as the cheater need only add an extra mark to the ballot when the voter is not looking (the old scheme of going to old-folks homes to 'help' them complete their ballots will get a new lease of life)
However, fairly strong protections for paper ballots are usual and cheating using electronic ballots is so open that this additional vulnerability is a drop in the bucket.

Love this video, but I think you missed something important; Primaries.

As you're probably aware, a Primary is an internal election among a party to determine which candidate to put forward.

In effect, this is kind of like a runoff election, but done before the election proper. The primary's goal is to get the political landscape down to just two candidates, which a plurality election then decides between. As a bonus, the primary system is self-enforcing; both "sides" of the political spectra have to do it, or else be at a disadvantage compared to the side that does (thanks, game theory!).

FPTP voting and plurality voting are two different things, plurality means the largest group picks the leader, regardless of their group has over 1/2 majority of the voting population. FPTP voting means you have to meet a certain minimum criteria of votes, and is used colloquially to describe America’s 270 electoral college votes rule, which means you have to get one more than half the 538 total electoral votes, or you have to have a majority vote. The terms are usually referring to the same group, if a majority exists then it’s also a plurality but pluralities can be below 50%, so long as they’re still the largest group.

i don’t think the center squeeze phenomenon is bad per sé, because... well, look at the past two or three decades of austerity politics. it’s awful having candidates who don’t embrace reform telling us to vote for their “moderate, reasonable position” and let them be “adults in the room,” then capitulate to opposing interests so hard that no one is happy. policy makers need to be opinionated, or the implementation is what gets spoiled, not the agenda. We can’t even say we’ve given a policy agenda a fair shake until going all-in on it: this way, when results of that implementation aren’t as planned, it’s easy for voters to see why policy makers went wrong and adjust their stances, without strategy being in the way of re-examining tangible results and asking if they’re what the voter really wants. It’s either “hard right” or “hard left” on any given axis in ℝn until we find all the solutions. Obviously this favors radicalism over stagnancy. That’s fine. Our political systems should push people toward introducing more prescriptions to make things better going forward for everyone, even though that will inevitably result in some mistakes: if we don’t make mistakes on each axis collectively we’ll never realize that they are mistakes. Eventually the solution space would contract as candidates realized where they should move their respective parties across lines, until candidates are on the right side of most issues, very decisively, on average.

I personally think Runoff is the best system because it's the hardest for a party to manipulate the results of. In plurality voting, they just need to claim more people wanted to vote for them then actually did, and in approval, a generally centrist, low impact party that won't rock the boat too much could claim far more support then they actually have because of how many unmarked secondary and tertiary votes they get. They don't even have to win, they just have to declare themselves the safest option for people who don't want the others to win and radically change the government for worse, and they're guaranteed back-up votes from a massive amount of voters. They could easily snowball this over time into winning elections they have no business winning out of pure fearmoungering that the other parties will do for them half the time. Because the votes arn't ranked, the only fight against the potential misinformation campaign would be personal accounts and/or a shift in the status que, both of which are fairly slow, grass roots methods that'll let multiple elections pass by before taking any actionable form.

Though instant run off isn't perfect, it does give a fairly accurate reading of how popular a party or canadate actually is or isn't, in a way that cannot be obfuscated or easily rephrased by a party's attempt at propaganda. Though the system still has flaws, having public access to raw, undeniable voter data helps everyone vote smarter, helps smaller parties figure out how to grow, and curbs the power of larger and more generalist parties that few actually want to pick as their first choice.

Another thing to consider in the Approval Voting case is that individual voters can (and generally do) have different Approval Ranges. The Chicken Effect seems like it could easily show up not in 'betrayal' of a secondary candidate, but in choosing to narrow one's approval range - being 'pickier' about their candidate choice, but in a fairly organic rather than strategic way. Participants still behave 'honestly', voting for who they approve of, but candidates are motivated to encourage voters to narrow their ranges to the minimum width that would include themselves; people who agree with them should encouraged to be radically fanatic to them, while people who agree less with them should be encouraged to be flexible and open-minded. These competing pressures on voters through campaigning could have some... interesting consequences, to say the lease. o_o

Incidentally, Yes to Approval Voting all the way; it's just important to be honest and analytical about where the flaws in a system are or might-be. :)

Approval voting seems weird to me, because it's a binary choice (in the form presented). But in real life, you are never 100% or 0% in favor of a candidate, you will be somewhere in between. So let's say I am 30% satisfied if party A wins, 60% if party B wins, and 80% if party C wins. I then have to pick my threshold for what "approving" means, which let's say is 50% in this example (i.e. I approve on any party that I am >50% satisfied if they win). By this metric, I'm going to approve B and C. The problem with this vote is that it reflects that I like B and C equally, which clearly does not reflect reality (since I am 20% more satisfied if C wins). I guess this could be fixed by uising a 1 to 10 scale.

Ireland uses preferential ordered (1 - however many candidates there are) approval voting.
In each constituency (divided by counties/population), there are a given number of seats that need to be filled. In my constituency, there are four. There is then a quota of votes which will be required to determine if a candidate is elected.
Basically, we order our preferences and each candidate in last position is knocked out, and this continues for as many rounds as are required to fill the four seats. Sometimes, if the third and/or fourth-place candidates don't reach the quota, they will need to be deemed elected by default in order to ensure the seat is filled. This angers many voters because it means that minor parties rarely make any progress in terms of being elected. It's also easy to exploit since there is no minimum votes required for your ballot to be accepted, e.g. you can choose to vote for only 1 candidate simply by writing "1" beside their name, if you wish. This means that if the person's "1" choice isn't elected, there is no "2" to keep the ballot alive, and so it is scrapped. This means other candidates get an opportunity to be elected rather than placing them all in order of preference. Usually, most people will just order their favourite candidates and exclude those they don't want elected. Unfortunately, this technique has yet to be learned by the boomer generation who still "follow the rules" and continue to vote for the same parties over and over and over again 🤦🏻‍♀️

There are 37 parties and each party has a list of 50 candidates. Our government has 150 seats, which have to be divided upon the party candidates who people voted for.
Each citizen has one vote. They can vote on one candidate of their choosing, of one party of their choosing.
After the deadline the votes are counted. When a party reaches a certain amount of votes they get a seat (total amount of votes / 150 seats = the amount of votes needed for 1 seat) - and eventually each party is given a certain amount of seats to distribute. Those seats are distributed to the party candidates with the most amount of votes. And those people who end up in the government work together to govern the country.

It's a rough summary but that a little bit of how it works. It re-creates the country's opinions into a smaller scale so we can still debate in a democracy type of way.

You can vote for a party and for a candidate.

The direct votes for the candidates got 7 candidates in.

To counter this, a party with 30% now gets now 42 instead of 30 places. And so there are 700 people by 299 constituencys.

What if you had a mix between approval and runoff, where you could vote for as many candidates as you like, but you can rank them too. For example, if there were four colors (red, blue, green, yellow) and I liked yellow the best, I could rank yellow a 10 (out of 1-10), but I also would not mind if blue won so I would rate blue a nine, green would be my third choice so I would rank him a four, and I hate red so I would rank him a 1. Then the total for each candidate would be averaged and the winner would have the highest average. In this system it would be like approval except that you would not have to strategically not vote for your second favorite because by voting honestly, you can still show that you like your first choice better, as the 9 that I gave blue would make his average lower than the 10 I gave yellow. Now, you could still vote strategically and vote ones beside your favorite person, but that would just show that you really want that person to win and it would end up with them winning. Also, there would be less of a reason to do that as voting honestly would also help your number 1 win.

I'm an Australian and I think you've made a slight error in your interpretation of our instant runoff at least. It often called Ranked Choice, or Compulsory Preferential Voting.

Firstly you have included the results from our proportionally elected upper house and assumed that the greens and others elected are in the center and squeezed by the two poles of the two parties, but that isn't the case.

There is plenty wrong with Australian democracy but our voting system is remarkably good.

Primer, I am  so glad you are making these intriguing videos. This one raises several questions in my mind, and I wonder if there is enough interest to run some more variations. I believe there is a trend in US elections toward voter frustration, which taken to the extreme would result in 0% turnout with voters approving of none of the candidates. Obviously, this is not probable, but we have seen at least two recent elections where voters were faced with choosing between the lesser of two disapprovals. Also, the two highest turnout elections in the last 100 years yielded less than 70% participation. Typical US elections yield far lower turnout. Do you think there is a way to simulate some of these negative factors we find in our real world environment? How would the ideal voting system mitigate these factors? I’m not a fan of majority voting in general and rather like the German system of proportional voting. You directly vote for a party and that party gets the number of seats proportional to their votes. If you get 10% of votes you have 10% of the seats. Combined with that about half the seats are voted directly as representatives of regional districts, but they don’t change the majority ratios. Even if you don’t win any of the regional representatives you still get 10% of the seats.
I think this could also help to get third party candidates on the map if for example two additional parties on each wing would form and get around 15% or something they would be able to organize, fund and promote a candidate in contrast to someone who would have to go without a party.

2nd topic: A second way of strategic voting in the Approval system I can think of would be to vote hated candidates out. Let’s imagine a scenario where purple is far to the Apple side of the spectrum and blue is far to the mango side and orange says either apples or mangos are fine. Neither purple nor blue would approve of oranges opinion that both is fine and would only want apples or only want mangoes. And both the extrem applistic and the extrem mangistic would fear the other end of the spectrum might win and because they don’t want they they cast an additional vote for the Centre. Let’s say 10 people would only approve of orange, 20 would approve both orange an purple and 24 would only approve purple, 15 would approve orange and blue and the remaining 31 would approve only blue. Orange would get 30 in normal voting, purple 44 and blue would get 46. Fearing that blue might win the 13 only purple voters additionally cast a vote for orange and fearing that purple might win 10 blue voters do the same, suddenly making the weakest faction the strongest with 53 votes.

Australian here - Instant Run off is called Preferential voting. The idea being that if you didn't get your first candidate choice, you might get your 2nd, 3rd etc.

However, what really happens is that the two major parties involved in policies that make them stink to people that support them look elsewhere.

To mitigate this, they establish net dragging parties. That is the people more progressive or conservative that stray to the extremes, will look to vote for these minor parties.

What use to happen is that the minor parties would then give their preferences to the major, they changed this because the fraud is to obvious. Rather, they just said, let the people decide the preferences.

What they know is that the people that are conservative are definitely not going to preference the extreme left party nor give their votes to the major left party. They will preference the more conservative party, but since the main voters will simply vote for the more center right, their preference vote for this party will be higher then the left of center parties.

In short, it didn't change anything, just gives the illusion of choice, as those in the minor parties vote for the major left or right party on Bills anyway.

Unfortunately, we don't have a direct plurality voting system in the US though. The popular vote is still factored in but the electoral colleges cast their votes based on the state or territory you live in and abnormalities where the electoral vote goes to a candidate that DIDN'T receive the popular vote have occurred.

So for example, I'm right-leaning and I live in NY state (not in the city). My vote never counts and has never counted in any election ever due to the overwhelming Democratic lead in NYC. Because of the sheer population and influence, NY is a state that has never voted red in the entire history of the US, and that will not change now.

Vice-versa, if I moved to a state like, say, Texas, my vote wouldn't matter as well, even though my candidate will always win that state. Because of the exact opposite effect. Texas has never voted blue in the history of the US. which means my vote isn't actually counted and never solidifies anything. It's just adding to the overwhelming majority lead.

The relationship with how much your vote actually matters is a weird one. Your vote continues to matter MORE in direct parallel with how volatile a state's voting preferences are. If a state is mostly red, but occasionally votes blue, your vote will matter a little, but not as much as a state that is around a 50/50 split.

Meaning that people who live in swing states ALWAYS have a stronger vote because their votes actually can influence the election.

So, the reason no voting system will actually be good is because of a theorem known as Arrow's Impossibility Theorem. There are four conditions necessary for a properly democratic voting system where one if which will always be violated. These four conditions are Non-dictatorship, the electoral system has to actually properly rank people's preferences and not just mimic a single voter's preferences; universality, the preferences of voters are preserved so long as people's preferences remain the same; Independence of Irrelevant Alternatives (IIA), given a choice between x and y, if z is introduced x and y should not change in ranking; and Pareto Efficiency, if every individual prefers one option to another, so must society's preferences be the same. No voting system can avoid running afoul of at least one of those rules, and that lack of ability of running afoul of those rules results in those flaws that you list.

I prefer plurality voting. It offers two simple maxims; one person one vote, and most votes wins. That is very easy to list out and makes it harder for shenanigans to happen. Not impossible, but harder and easier to spot. It also offers a strong government compared with one split up into multiple parties. It is much more likely for there to be a majority that can just take the wheel and get things done according to their agenda. It is okay for there to be king-makers, that isn't fatal to a democracy. It is also okay for people to strategically pick their candidates. It isn't unfair, or unreasonable, to expect and allow people to be rational agents capable of making up their own minds about what they are willing to sacrifice and what they aren't.

First, thanks for making this! I agree with others; I've always loved CGP Grey's series on voting systems, and the more people who spread the word about different voting systems, the better. I do think that his series does a better job explaining, but that may just be differences in how our minds work -- it's very possible that there are people out there for whom this video does a better job than his at explaining the different systems.

I do see a bit of a problem with the, "let's just list one flaw with each system" idea, though. Because plurality voting has far, far more than just one flaw. In addition to the spoiler effect, there's also complacency in the two major parties (which you touched on)... which leads to so many other problems. The fact that they only have to be marginally better than one other candidate means that they don't really have to listen to their constituents at all. There's no accountability... or, in the case of countries with a Citizens United-like rule, there's accountability, but only to their big donors. Not to their constituents.

Then there's the extremism problem. Under a plurality system, the most important decision -- exactly WHO is going to represent each party -- is made during the primary... and moderate voters (who just want to live their lives in peace) don't typically vote in primaries as much as voters with a cause do. So candidates win primaries by being more extreme. Sometimes this is good, when it comes to huge parties that primarily have corporate interests at heart, but it also leads to a government that's incapable of compromise, and therefore incapable of action.

(On a side note, plurality elections are also much more expensive to hold, because you have to hold two separate elections -- the primary and the general.)

Speaking of primaries, I recently had a local primary where there were, I think, 9 candidates for my party for one office. Most of whom I liked. But I had to pick one, because... plurality. Even though that really didn't make much sense. :( And then I think the winner of that primary won with about 34% of the total vote. Which, last I checked, is not over 50%, and is therefore not a majority. RCV (as well as most other voting systems) has a simple fix for this (and small correction to the video: with RCV, you don't necessarily keep eliminating until there are only two candidates left. You keep eliminating candidates, and then re-tallying the first non-eliminated choice on each ballot, until one candidate has over 50% of the total vote. At which point they're declared the winner, because they have an actual majority of votes).

Plurality voting also contributes to low voter turnout, because... well... if your choices are: vote for the lesser of two evils, or vote for somebody who has no chance of winning and may actually be blamed for the next best choice losing the election... you're not going to feel hugely motivated to go to the polls. You may even leave with kind of a sick feeling in your stomach, which is the exact opposite of the empowered feeling a voter should have when leaving the polls.

Which brings me to the data problem. Voting is, in many ways, a poll. But a plurality vote really, really sucks as a poll, because the only data it can truly provide is who most of the voters felt was the lesser of the two evils. It says nothing about where the voters actually stand on issues. There's nothing to analyze.

And then there's the indirect effect that plurality voting has on society at large. As a fortysomething who grew up in the USA, I literally have never experienced a general election where the majority of ads have focused on actually promoting a candidate. The majority of ads in any major general election are all about how horrible the other candidate is. We all -- and I do mean ALL of us -- have been trained over the course of our entire lives to vote out of fear of the other party. To the point where it's almost strange to think of a world in which we could go to the polls to vote FOR a candidate, not AGAINST a candidate (at least, not without risking the spoiler effect). This keeps us from expecting too much from our elected "representatives" (which I'm sure is just fine with them). But it also hardwires an "us vs. them" mentality into our brains, and has made our society even more divisive than it would otherwise be. I doubt this happened deliberately. It's just that, with plurality voting, negative advertising is just more effective than positive advertising (not to mention easier for the candidates), so it's always (ALWAYS) been used, by both of the major parties, always. With instant runoff (I'm not sure about approval, just because I haven't given it much thought), it's proven that negative advertising just doesn't work as well, because voters have more than two realistic choices... and, from what I've seen of local elections, this leads to a much saner society.

So. In short, with plurality voting, we have voters who are pressured to vote out of fear of the party they hate the most. They're rarely excited to vote, and really, everyone who isn't also a major donor to a campaign is disenfranchised, because even if they do vote, their candidate has no real accountability to them, and everybody knows it. It's also expensive, gives no useful information about where the majority of voters actually stand, and leads to divided societies.

...and I still feel like I'm forgetting something. The list of problems with plurality voting is so, so long.
And you completely ignore proportional voting, which is a common, proven, and effective voting system. Why?
While still my last favorite, Plurality isn't all bad. It's simplicity lets it be the fastest to count, and have the fewest opportunities for mistakes or tampering.

I encourage everyone to learn about other (more ?) interesting voting systems :

Majority Judgment : you can also be honest about your first choice and, a bit like approval, you can decide to betray or not your seconde and other choices. It has other problems. For example, a really appreciated candidate can loose, because in this system, it is not the best who is choosen, but the one with the best "median mention", some kind of balance between approvals and disapprovals.

Condorcet system : it is a family of voting systems but the main idea is always to choose the candidate that is preferred to any other candidate in a 1vs1 battle. Problem : it does not always exist (=Condorcet Paradox). Using the "Randomized Condorcet" to decide in case of paradox, you can practically remove strategical voting. The main problem witht this system (which is very small), is what we call the "Tyranny of the majority", which means the majority (>50% of the pop) decides, even if the decision is really really bad for the other people (<49%).

I'd like to point out that the major issue leading to two-party systems is not in fact any single of these methods but the fact it's single-winner voting systems. If you instead have a system where the ruling party doesn't merely need to represent a simple majority but an absolute majority and you leave room for the concept of party coalitions, you are suddenly in a situation where you still might vote for your actual favorite even though you don't think they've got a chance to win, just because you might manage to make them important enough to be a coalition partner. Like, say the most successful party gets 45%, the second most successful party gets 40% and the third most successful party gets 15% of the votes. Assuming that the two most successful parties are on opposing positions on the political spectrum, the third party will be able to form a coalition with one of the two from which a government will be made. This government will represent the will of 55%-60% of the people (vs what might only be 30% in a winner-takes-all system) and it will need to make compromises, particularily because it is still facing off against a strong political opposition in the parliament.
The general issue in single-winner voting systems is that whatever was your first choice doesn't get represented at all unless they actually win

What if, instead of a single winner, you had a representative council?

Now, if Orange = 35%, Green = 30%, Purple = 20% and assorted fringe characters total 15% ... then that is the makeup of the executive council, which is great. Nobody has an overall majority, which means trade-offs must be made.

On the specific question of mangos v apples, there is an orange-purple coalition that gives apples a natural 55% majority, possibly a little more with the independents being divided on the issue. This is good, because most of the population want apples. Green doesn't care much about the apple/orange debate - and offers to collaborate for some cooperation on ugly housing - but nobody needs their support to push apples though. Why? Cus, it's a majority public opinion... it shouldn't involve compromise, and it doesn't.

On the housing debate, orange mostly wants modern houses, but purple (their natural ally during the great fruit debate) is split. Green is also fairly split... and the future housing decision looks like it could go either way. But now the independents, who didn't much care which fruit - but are highly motivated on housing, become king-makers in a split field.

In such a representational system, if people can vote on approval - they can perhaps support a one-issue candidates on matters of housing, whilst also supporting their larger ideological parties. And that's good... it means that these fringe issues have strong advocates in the executive council and can press their views - either by resolving split field - or by offering small but critical support to a major party on a split issue in return for reciprocal support on their special interest.

Such a system means that parties are not necessarily trying to thwart each other at any cost, but rather seeking out compromises and forming fluid alliances on a per-question basis...

... and that is far better for the national conversation.

Contrast to: Lame duck majority presidents hamstrung and held impotent by an oppositional senate... and the anger and polarisation this causes in the electorate.

Personally, I say do away with "parties" ... the only people that should be "whipping" the politicians are the folks back home. We need a diverse field, a free choice of tie colours and far less of a "them-v-us" mentality.

An executive council is stronger than a single leader, healthier for the country, should be a fairly eclectic mix of general alignments and special interests - and, importantly, be beholden only to their local base - not some overriding party line.

Decisions should be made on the popular support for the question asked, every time - not on the colour of the tie that the person raising the question wears... and nobody should be afraid that backing minority interests might cost them their wider more ideological voice.

While this is an interesting thought experiment, it is leaving aside one major mechanism present in most democracies around the world: the parliament. The purpose of parliaments and distribution of power proportionally to number of votes is that, unless a party has at least half the votes (and thus high popularity), it is required to compromise with other parties in order to approve measures. This is, or should be, the mechanism through which the will of the people is satisfied somewhat in proportion to how many other voters share their ideas.
The reason undemocratic results are reached has to do much less with the voting mechanism itself than with the existence of electoral circles or regions. These are the main issue in many countries, including my own, where electors in sparsely populated areas that elect only one or two representatives can only vote for one or two parties, since every vote that goes towards a small party won't be represented and is essentially wasted.

Can you go into more depth on score voting systems in another video? I was writing up an idea for a voting system as I watched which basically amounted to that— you’d vote for as many people aa you want, but order them in terms of preference ( so like, Ben is your 1st vote, Chuck is your second, Sasha is your third, so on and so forth). It seems like the issues with center-squeeze and the chicken dilemma would come up less often in this or any other score voting system, since it’d function like approval voting, but you’d have less of an incentive to get greedy with your votes since you still probably like your second choice enough to not risk them losing to your third— especially in a grading system where you could be extra flexible with how you rate your choices, increasing the chance of someone at least rating their second honestly instead of rating them very poorly or not rating them at all. It wouldn’t fix the chicken dilemma, but it’d reduce its prominence which gives it a bit of an edge in my opinion.

If there are any new problems this kind of system would introduce, I’d like to see them elaborated upon at some point. I can try to do my own research as well, but I’m not exactly sure where to look— maybe Google Scholar could have some research into the flaws of this kind of system?

Edit: A precursory skim over the Wikipedia article brings up a few interesting extra points. For example, an extra instant runoff round between the top two choices would help to prevent the victory of a majority loser. Other than that, I don’t see any mention of problems that don’t already exist in the approval voting system...

Why not have a "disapproval" voting system that works inversely to the approval system? Instead of only voting for everyone you would be ok with, you would vote for everyone you don't like. It would be like if every candidate had every vote, until the voters took their votes away from them. This would have less flaw than an approval system because, for one, when a voter feels neutral about a candidate, they wouldn't care about either approving them OR disapproving them. Therefore, they would instead give their vote to their neutral opinion where before they wouldn't have voted at all. Secondly, if a voter doesn't feel confident about any of the candidates, instead of entirely abstaining they would have to go and vote to have a voice. This was incite the voters to do more research, and most likely not disapprove the candidate they feel most comfortable with -- which would then make the voters that would have otherwise never have voted instead vote for their honest preference. Finally, in the mind of a voter, they would most likely not care about disapproving anyone but the person they hate the most. This would hopefully subside the "chicken game" that happens within the normal approval system, as well as blocking out anybody truly unfit to get in office.

Better solution:
Runoff + approval = ranked weighted votes
Rank all candidates
1st place gets some multiplier, and 2nd gets a lower multiplier and so forth.
Voters may vote for as many or as few candidates as they want. You can be honest or betray, same as before, but the more favored candidates still get more votes. The way I see 3rd Parties in a FPTP system is that they offer utility in the form of threatening a major party with an election defeat if they don't address the concerns of a minority that is large enough to split the vote. Actually, I'd argue there's no reason to vote in a plurality system. Most of us live in safe seats or districts, where the winning party is almost certainly pre-determined, and short of a massive swing nothing will change it. There's no point in a Californian voting Republican in a presidential election, for example. I've only ever lived in safe seats where my vote has not mattered. Furthermore, unless your vote is the single one that changes the outcome of the election, it is largely wasted anyway. Example - in the 2015 elections, UKIP and the Greens took about 10% of the vote each, but achieved 0% of the seats won, meaning that 10% of the people voting recieved no representation. Furthermore, all those who did NOT vote for the party which went on to form a government could also reasonably be argued achieved no representation, since their MPs cannot significantly affect legislation.

Until our voting systems change, for most people within most countries democracy is largely pointless.

I don't quite understand how the "flaw" of the instant run-off system is wrong. Disregarding the odds of 3 extremely close parties/candidates making that situation occur, how are either of the outcomes a flaw? Either green wins by appealing to the orange voters as 2nd choice or orange wins by having the most first and second votes remaining. There's one more element to simulate in these models: voter turnout.

Candidates might have an approval range, but I would model voters who can also have what I would refer to as the 'apathy range', where if a voter has multiple favored candidates they'd be happy with, but no candidate so far away that they actively hate, that potential voter is not actually motivated enough to cast a vote in the first place. These models only work for tracking voters who showed up and if the election matches the opinions of voters, but the opinions of voters won't always be the same as the opinions of the population as a whole. I would argue that the goal of an election system is to find the candidate where the majority population approves, even if the majority population haven't cast a vote.

Hypothetically, this results in scenarios where more centrist candidates have a lot of support from shared votes, but because their voter base is moderate, they also may not be far enough from most candidates to actually show up to the polls, resulting in a scenario where even if a middle of the road candidate has majority approval and should win an instant runoff or approval contest of the whole population, they still lose the election from failure to convert popular support into actual votes. Of course, the more extreme the opposing candidates are the better the moderate fares, but if there's a plethora of moderates, the most centrist among them should, I assume, win in popular opinion but lose in election. It could be worthwhile to explore just what changes in these models with applying different characteristics to potential voters and not just assume the entire population votes.

In Germany we use a percent based system in which each party gets as many percent of the seats as it had in an election as long as it has won at least 5 percent or three constituencies. In these constituencies, the candidate who gets the most votes wins without ranking or anything like that, but these what we call direct mandates have no influence on the percentage distribution in parliament because all other parties get extra seats, so-called equalizing mandates, if one party gets more direct mandates than it is entitled to according to the general result in seats. The problem with this is that the parliament can become very large.

So, the assessment that Plurality is the Worst is biased, because we have experienced Plurality voting for the longest, thoroughly explored its strategies, exploitations, vulnerabilities, and flaws. I would attest that none of these three are inherently better than any other. They all pose their own unique benefits and problems.

One misconception is that the United States uses Plurality voting. This is only partially true - US Presidential elections actually utilize Majority voting; similar to Plurality, but with the caveat that to be declared winner, one must have more than half of all votes, not merely more votes than anyone else. Failure to meet this greater-than-half margin has multiple contingencies set forth in the Constitution, but in all cases except the absolute-last-resort case of House Speaker Becomes Acting President, there is always some greater-than-half margin. It does improve the situations pure Plurality voting can cause, but it still does have most of the flaws, strategizing, and issues that Plurality voting in general has. If one or more States wanted choose how to cast their Electoral votes via Approval voting, I'd be down, but I would want to see Approval voting in practice at a State level for at least a decade before Constitutional revision and adoption at the Federal level.

Approval voting fails if A) people just approve of their top favored candidate or B) people don't approve of anyone.

Broader issue. Our present political system (in the US) talks about things as if there were a linear left to right spectrum, but that's not actually representative of issues people care about, which is why we never get a president most people approve of. While there is some tendency to cluster certain viewpoints, this tends to happen more due to tribal affiliation. This is so bad that anyone from within those tribes tends to automatically assume you are in the other tribe and hold all of its (purported) views if you disagree with them on a single thing.

While the two primary tribes collectively gather some significant portion of the populace, and probably a larger proportion of the voting populace, there is a still larger group that regards issues independently. There is also the issue of how intensely a given person cares about a given issue. So to accurately model this (still very pared down view), you would need a ten dimensional space in which each voter has a different sized radius for each issue. Obviously if you only have two candidates and first past the post (as in, the one who attains 50%+ of the voting space) you still just get two parties. And that's why the voting system matters.

Then there is the Electoral College, which is another can of worms.

Condorcet voting is an interesting ranked voting system that avoids the center squeeze effect but is vulnerable to other problems. What it does is run a binary election between each candidate, using the ranked values of each of the voters to determine which of the two candidates in each binary election those voters would pick over the other. This can lead to, in some cases, a rock-paper-scissors issue where there is no condorcet winner, but that's fairly rare. The up and down side of it on its own with people voting honestly is that the condorcet winner tends to be a compromise candidate. This means, in the "all in a line" setup, the moderate will tend to win...unless people vote strategically.

The major problem, though, is that it tends to encourage those with passion to vote strategically which is harmful.

So, I propose the following: A ranked ballot that performs both an instant runoff and a condorcet election in parallel. Independently determine the winner of these. If they agree, the agreed-winner is (obviously) the winner. If they disagree (but each has exactly one final winner), do an instant runoff/condorcet between the two! It's now the same procedure, when you have two and only two candidates. If there is a condorcet cycle (A beats B, B beats C, but C beats A in the respective binary elections), and one of the members is the winner of the Instant Runoff, then that one wins (because he's a condorcet tie-winner and obviously he was a more passionate choice overall).

Finally, if there's a condorcet cycle and the IRV winner isn't in it, the whole procedure is repeated with just the condorcet cycle and the IRV winner. (Condorcet winners win THE MOST binary elections, which may mean that, in a crowded field, the IRV winner didn't lose to all or even most of the Condorcet cycle-of-winners, just didn't win against as many other candidates as they did. It is also possible that the condorcent cycle winners got knocked off the IRV tickets early despite being second or third choices for a fair number of voters, so the IRV can turn out differently.) If the net result of the repeated procedure is ever the same as the starting point (i.e. the repeating procedure didn't work), the final round IRV winner wins on the grounds that the condorcet cycle proves there's no good compromise.

The goal here is to avoid the "squeeze" effect with the condorcet method and avoid the possibility of passion getting in the way of moderation from the condorcet effect. With the level of complexity here, there's no really good way to predict how the parallel elections will go, so strategy is almost impossible, and thus voting honestly is the best strategy. It will tend to reward the candidate who has the most passion behind him right up until he's so polarizing that he divides people sharply, while not having support for the compromise choice really work against him.

Let's say Trump is the super-polarizing candidate where people adore him or loathe him, Romney is a "compromise" candidate that passionate Trump supporters would accept if Trump really can't win, and passionate Trump-haters will either have as their first choice or will accept if the polarizer on the other side can't win, and Hillary is the super-polarizing candidate on the far side.

Condorcet will have Romney as the clear winner, assuming everybody votes honestly. If they vote strategically, everyone who cares passionately leaves Romney off, and some of Romney's voters are having to strategically vote for the polarizing candidate they hate least if they suspect this is happening. This is the issue with Condorcet.

On the other hand, IRV will be harder to predict without knowing exact numbers of supporters. But if we assume Romney is more of a spoiler for Trump than for Hillary, the first round likely has the very passionate Trump vote in second place to Hillary's passionate voters, with Romney in last. IRV second round of Trump v. Hillary will likely give it to Trump (though, again, it depends on whether Romney was more spoiler for Hillary or Trump).

Let's say it comes down to Trump winning the IRV path and Romney the condorcet path. This means now we do a binary round of Trump v. Romney, and see if the "we hate Trump" + "we actually like Romney" vote is bigger than the "we love Trump" vote. (Given that Romney won the condorcet, it's probably going to him. This...might not be the best example; I think I hsould've had Bernie in there to ensure the condorcet winner wasn't automatically going to beat all other candidates in a head-to-head matchup.)

Thought you should know that that infographic you show of an Australian election is a bit misleading. Those are the results for a senate election, which uses a multiple-winner system. In that particular election, each Australian state elected 12 senators* using a system called "Proportional Representation by Single Transferable vote" which is MUCH more complicated than the Instant Run Off system described in the video. Though the actual method of filling in the ballot paper is similar ie. numbering boxes 1 - 12 (or more if so inclined).

Our lower house elections DO use the simple, single-member type of instant run-off you talk about, but in general the results are much more 2-party dominant. In that same election, the results were Red - 69, Blue - 76, everyone else - 3.

Despite that, I'm still an avid fan of the system, and would strongly recommend adopting it over plurality voting, which, frankly, is broken and poisonous.

*the numbers don't add up because we also have two territories that also elect 2 senators each

Approval voting is unnecessary. In fact I can not see what it does in your example that is different from the way Preferential Voting works in practice. All its benefits, and then, some are contained in "instant runoff" called Preferential Voting in Australia. To avoid the Chicken Problem you just make it extremely difficult and out of the hands of parties to manipulate.

You have not broken down the real issue which is to blend the benefits of single seat electorates where the electorates choose the candidate, not political hacks, but many remain unrepresented with no-one elected to speak for them, and proportional voting where the overall representations of Parties more accurately reflect the people's percentage choice. The problem is party hacks in Proportional Systems choose their favourites and order them in voting lists so the Party's choices are at the top and more likely to win and thus be beholden to the Party selector and not the voter.

This problem is fixed in Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory. Seats are assembled in regional groupings. The ACT is 5 seats in 5 districts, a total of 25 seats available. People vote for 5 successful candidates in their district, so there is a connection between the successful candidates and most of the voters. The voter numbers the candidates in order from 1 being the most preferred to the number of candidates being the most disliked.

Anybody with the least votes is eliminated and the election officials go to who is next (No 2) on their list of choices and that vote is passed on.

Simple maths tells you that a candidate with ⅙ th of the vote + 1 has a winning "quota" (more than the ⅕ th votes, plus the balance of unsuccessful votes) so any candidate with the quota is then elected to a seat. Their surplus votes are passed onto their second choice, generally resulting in a group of candidates voted in even if most choose the first on the list.

The least favoured are thus eliminated until the 5 candidates are all elected for that district. A happy marriage of proportional and seat based voting.

The obvious problem with this is what is called donkey voting, those who can't be bothered number from the top down favouring whoever is lucky enough to be at the top of the list. That has been fixed by randomising the ballots, nobody is on the top of the list of all ballots.

One thing you have not dealt with is the serious issue of stopping voter fraud, voter suppression and gerrymandering. In Australia EVERYBODY gets a vote, NO EXCEPTIONS and MUST vote (in practice pick up a ballot and put it in the ballot box) secret voting, the great Australian innovation, prevents anyone telling you what to do with your ballot once you have it.

Gerrymandering is outlawed and voting boundaries are controlled by an independent Voting Commission NOT by the politicians who obviously will rig them if they get the chance.

Just to let you know, the Australian Senate does not use Instant Runoff Voting. It uses IRV's multi-winner version, Single Transferable Vote. IRV is used in the Australian House of Representatives only, and mostly fails in electing third parties. The lower house is dominated by two parties (one a coalition of different regional parties that functions as a single party at the federal level), with third parties controlling at most one seat each in the current parliament. STV is generally better at giving representation to third parties because, in the multi-winner framework, it can also transfers "surplus" votes of candidates which are extremely popular. STV's system defines a vote quota which much be reached to get elected, and candidates which exceed the quote will have some of their support moved to their voters second choices.

And neither are particularly good at growing third party support, compared with something like a Proportional Representation system.

@Primer What would happen? If you layered an Approval Voting system under an Instant Run Off system what happens?

So first you look at round 1 of the Instant Run Off to select the bottom two parties.
Then the bottom two parties are compared for Approval Voting (against the whole vote and not just those that voted for either in the Instant Run Off) and the loser of this Approval Voting sub-round is eliminated.
Wash rinse repeat until someone has enough votes to win.

This plays the center squeeze of the Instant Run Off system against a far more complex chicken dilemma of the Approval Voting system, but what actually happens?

I think this creates a reverse center squeeze, right? Alternatively, the extreme complexity of the chicken dilemma might actually solve the center squeeze and result in honesty always being the best policy?

Plurality voting has an interesting hidden "benefit" of the creation of big tent parties.

The reason Instant Runoff still turns into a two party system is because it is ultimately still a plurality system, as the runoff only happens to the least popular candidate if no candidate has a plurality, repeat until plurality, and more often than not that'll involve two parties seeing as how it's easier to get half out of two instead of getting half out of three. Meanwhile Approval doesn't require a plurality at all, just whoever gets the bigger number wins.
Personally, I would go with Instant Runoff for single-winner elections, while Approval can be done with multiple-winner elections, with maybe a proportion caveat so that if an X-party gets % approval but none of the party wins (due to many votes being diluted across many candidates for instance), the most approved candidate of a party is put in so the stations aren't flooded with the more popular winners. That way the multiple-winner parties can actually build bases that can compete in Instant Runoff elections, and the multiple-winner elections can have alternate voices instead of the most popular ones.

Though really personally, I would like no parties and for people to vote locally for local issues instead of dragging their local politics up to the federal level to be enforced upon the entire country, but that's just me.

We had instant runoff presidential election in 1922 in Poland. Only around 550 people were voting so it was easy to manipulate with votes. There were 5 candidates, in the first 4 election rounds the one candidate (let's call him "A") had the best score but lost in the end. And the one that win in the end (let's call him "B") in the first roud was on the 4th place - he got only 62 votes in first round.  In second round voters of "C" candidate, who was 3rd in first round (getting 103 votes) was betrayed in second round and got only 10 votes - if they voted "C" they would eliminate the "B" but they didn't like "A" and believed only "B" can win against "A" so they eliminated their candidate on purpose! In the end voters of "A" accused election as being manipulated by "foreigners" (as C was candidate of national minorities and A was candidate of nationalists, and C get into next rounds only thanks to the votes of C voters - he would lost in 2nd,3rd and 4th round without them) and it resulted in widespread outrage among some people that ended with assasination of the elected president a few days after election. If it was plurality system either A or D (not even mentioned earlier) would probably win (and in the end D become  the next president a few days after assasination).

While the approval system is clearly the winner here, it has another weakness that relates more to its real world application:
Approval system, especially in countries that do have 3 or more noteworthy parties, might overwhelm voters. Instead of gravitating to a single camp that for the most part lines with their opinions, they would also need to properly evaluate other camps if they want to really make good use of their voting powers (which, tbh, is a thing people should already do in any voting system, but, you know). But by being overwhelmed with SO MANY PARTIES, where, unlike your example, don't have just 2 subjects they have opinions of, we might be talking about tens of important subjects for each, it will naturally get confusing, fast.

Choice overload exists in plurality voting, but in an approval system, where your voting power have so much more nuance, suddenly there's less of an "us v.s. them", and you can no longer rely on the easy choice to be the be all and end all of your thought process. After all,
