I think how MMP (Mixed Member Proportional) is used in New Zealand is a good example of how plurality voting can work.
Each person gets to vote on their local seat (which is decided in a plurality fashion), as well as contributing a party vote to the overall pool.
Using simpler numbers as an example, let's imagine there are 150 seats avaiable in parliament. Of these 150, 50 seats are assigned specifically to districts, while the remaining 100 are decided on the outcome of the party vote.
In order to be represented in parliament, a party must win either a local seat, or receive at least 5% of the party vote.
A party could win 20 local seats, but 60% of the party vote, and therefore net 80 seats total. Alternatively, a smaller party could just win the one local seat and still be represented, or no local seats but 10% of the party vote, and therefore have 10 seats in parliament.

It takes a lot of power away from a two party system, unless there's a blowout like there was this year.

One system that I never see being mentioned in elections videos is elections with second turns. If none of the candidates  achieves more than 50% percent of the votes in the first turn, than the two most voted candidates will compete again in the second turn. This away the winner always win with the majority of the votes. Tactical voting  still happens though. Let say for exemple,  there  is 2 "up" candidates and 3 "down" candidates, and that the "down" have 54% of the votes, and that the "up" have 46%, and that the votes are shared equally between the two sides, than in the first turn each candidate from the "up" would have 23%, and each candidate from the "down" would have 18% of the votes, so in the second turn there would be two "up" candidates, although the majority of the population prefers the "down". To avoid that, the voters tend to clump around the biggest candidate from each side. Still, my country, Brazil, who uses this system, have a lot more than two major parties.

I don't agree that Instant runoff is better than Plurality in this depiction. It seems more to depend on which type of candidate you would like to consistently win; A focused or generalized one.

For example, in Plurality, the best way for a candidate to try and combat the 3rd party Spoiler effect is to not take such a hard stance on any one subject to keep as many of the less focused individuals on their side. Since the extremes of any spectrum are usually sparsely populated, this should (in theory) keep as many votes as possible away from third party (which generally ends up more focused). However, if they decided to be focused and take a hard stance on anything, they risk alienating enough people to the 3rd party which could then result in a loss to the spoiler effect.

In Instant runoff, It instead punishes candidates that do not have a focused opinion on a subject. So the strategy to counter the Center Squeeze effect is to make sure your stance on a subject is greater than your opponents. This then shuts down the chance at a generalized candidate because it discourages trying to pander to as many people as possible. This increases the likelihood that they will at least do something, but also increases the likelihood that they are not actually what most people wanted, but instead that of a focused group of the populace.

To note, I don't think either is very good. I'm just saying I don't think it is accurate to say one is better than the other. It really just changes the type of candidate you will get. I am not focusing on number of parties or if the 3rd or more parties are cut out. The parties do not matter. I am only focusing on what the candidate would be like on the issues involved because the issues and how candidates would act on them is what is going to be important to the people.

In my experience with IRV in Australia, having two major parties (or one party vs one permanent coalition) is seen as a feature not a bug. Because we're a Westminster system, the controller of the majority of the lower House forms the executive government. Whenever a third party or multiple independents prevents either major party from ruling in their own right, the general public sees them as a weak government, puppeted by the small "unrepresentative" faction that holds the balance of power. Having a system that produces that result only occasionally (when both major parties really do lack solid support), prevents us from being talked into switching over to a much worse system (like first-past-the-post.)

(Personally, I prefer the Doge of Venice system of mixed rounds of sortion and selection.)

@Primer I have to say I was a little disappointed with the treatment of ranked choice voting here. In particular, it's misleading to say "Ranked choice" is synonymous to Instant Runoff Voting, as Instant Runoff is just one of many ways to handle the results of ranked choice voting, and is usually regarded as one of the worst way to do so. Its only benefit is that it's easy to understand. For example, the flaws you listed would not exist in a Condorcet method for ranked choice voting, as it would guarantee a strong candidate who can beat any other candidate 1-on-1 will always win.

For your approval voting example, I think the issue is I don't know of any way to reduce strategic voting under an approval system, unlike ranked choice voting. This may be marginally better than Plurality, but you can guarantee a high dose of toxity and infighting because of that, unlike Condorcet methods which does a better job in reducing strategic voting. Ultimately, each voter's radius for that imaginary circle will be different, and a lot of strategic voting relies on convincing your constituents to draw a tighter circle to avoid giving your votes to purple (if you are orange). In fact, all scored voting system has this issue where you are very heavily incentivized over time to make your scores more extreme to "make them count".

Ok, this video is pretty nicely done if we speak of mathematics. But Approvalvoting has some major flaws if we look at it from a sociological position: Some vots from some voters have more value than votes of other voters, let me explain: A and B are politically close together, C has different ideas. So lets say out of 100 people 50 people approve A (A50), and 48 approve B (B48). Furthermore 36 approve C. (C36). They only approve the person in which cycle they are, like in the video. A would win - ok, A is the Person the most people want. It´s fair. But if we take a closer look, we find:
B is second, which could mean: A becomes president, B becomes vice-president. C gets nothing. Now lets look at the the votes wich only went for 1 Person: We maybe get C32, A30, B28. The 20 people voting for both A and B now elected the president and the vice-president, because their vote had double value compared to the others. If they olny voted for one, they would most likely elect just the president and not the vice-president.
So approvalvoting does not work if you vote more than 1 designated Person into 1 designated postition. It still remains a "the winner takes it all" system. “First past the post” is the voting system used here in Britain. Everyone votes for their local MP, and depending on if they’re red, blue, yellow, green, or whatever, that contributes to the political party. The party needs a certain number of seats in parliament to seat their prime minister. If no parties get that, the leading party need to merge with another party in order to get those seats required. First past the post isn’t proportional representation, nor is it winner takes all. It’s literally just a line you have to cross or you lose.

As an Australian voter who is not a student of politics by any means, I feel like the phenomena of two major parties in Aus might be less to do with the squeeze effect and more to do with the fact that Australian voters have the option of not listing every preference. If a voter only wants to nominate one candidate on their ballot, they can and their preference runoff will be based on that one candidate's default preference, which in turn is dictated more or less always by what deals their parties have made prior to the election. Party preference deals are where a lot of Aussie politicking occurs, and a lot of voters unintentionally betray their honest preferences when they don't fill in all the preferences on the ballot.

Minimax says the following: to reach the best result, you must seek the minimization of losses.

Therefore, the best voting system would be the following:
1) For N candidates, there would be voting N-1 rounds
2) While there are still two or more candidates:
2.1 ) People vote the one they want out of competition.
2.2 ) Remove the most voted candidate
3.3) Go to 2
3) The left candidate is the chosen one.

We have plurality voting in germany and we have way more than two parties. The way you make it work is by letting a single party win only if they get more thab 50 percent. Otherwise you form a coalition of the most voted. Or (in case of mayor elections) if there is no clear winner (50%+), there's a new election of the two favorites. So it is a mix of plurality and Instant runoff, whenever it best fits. And that's how it works in at least most european countries and aus and nz as far as i know.

For those interested in better alternatives: In the Dutch multi-party system, elections happen via open-list proportional representation. We vote for which two politicians we approve most of, which results in an increase in the amount of 'seats'(in parliament) a party has.

National and provincial elections both have you vote for which party you believe should have more influence in the government(or Cabinet). Theres no voting districts, as all votes are mathematically translated into parliamentary seats (X amount of votes = X seats assigned to party A). Tactical/strategic voting is undesirable, as the government is always a coalition between two or more parties.

The only flaw (AFAIK)in this system is that it is bicameral. Both chambers of parliament have the same role, though only one chamber's Members of Parliament can have a secondary salary, opening it up to corruption.

All these systems have a shared fundamental flaw.
The voter needs to know where they are on that compass, and they need to know where the candidates are on the compass.
They also need to know what that compass even means and whether they think their position on it seems reasonable or not.
On top of that if one candidate on the opposite side of your spectrum is offering a solution to a problem which is much more important to you than your general opinion of their politics, the system breaks for that voter.
And finally, most importantly - The voter needs to be interested enough in the system, compass and politics in general to care more about knowing possible outcomes than how the candidate's hair look on pictures or about their words more than their soothing voice.

What about approval instant-runoff? You can rank the candidates but can use numbers multiple times: you could give a 1 to two candidates, a 2 to three candidates and so on. That would fix the betrayal problem of just approval voting because you could prefer one candidate and the center-squeeze problem of instant-runoff voting because you could rank two candidates equally.

IR and approval voting would incentivize candidates to be nicer to each other because you're competing for second place with your opponent's voters on top of holding your own base. Two candidates like Hillary and Bernie would have no reason to smear each other because they're very likely to be the second choice of each other's voters if they play it nice. In a multi-party IR system, someone like Trump who compulsively lashes out at his opponents would have a very hard time to gain voters outside his base. But in a plurality system with two options, whoever dislikes the only other candidate more will have every reason to hold their nose and vote for Trump, lacking any better options.

Could a hybrid of Instant Runoff and Approval Voting be possible?

As in, a System that takes into account the interests of the Approval voter, but accounts a knock-out system for candidates who trail.

In prospect, at least based on the explanation in the video, it does seem to alleviate some level of the Center Squeeze and Chicken problems with both systems.

Center Squeeze would be weakened due to people voting for multiple candidates based on Approval.
And the Chicken Dilemma would be weakened due to the knockout aspect knocking out the candiate with the lesser number of votes.

So as long as people don't vote for every single candidate, it would end up sorting itself out a fair bit.

A system of that nature also would help a lot in multi-party systems where there are a large number of candidates, as it would be better reflective of the Candidates the people want, AND support as it would have the Approval Rating aspect integrated into it.

No, but seriously, thank you for being sensible. One thing that you didn't mention -- that maybe would fit in its own separate video -- is the foundational assumption that popularity voting is the best family of election methods in the first place. In every area of life, in every job outside of politics (and maybe some reality contest TV shows), we all agree that popularity does not determine fitness for a job. You don't go into an interview and hand your potential employers a list of people who like you, and then lie to them about what you'll do for them to make them like you, too. Instead, you hand them a resume showing your skillset, and you talk about your previous experience, and you answer their questions about the job so they -- the people who actually know what the job requires -- can decide if you're a good fit. So if we know that evidence, experience, and proof of capability, as judged by experts who already know what the job entails, are all required for every other job in the world ... then why do we throw all that out the window when deciding who gets to make the laws that literally determine other people's entire lives (and often, deaths)? Why do we reduce the most important jobs' qualifications down to an American Idol contest?

Those are all First Past Post, First Past Post doesn't refer to how the votes are counted but instead refers to a party getting into government only after it had won the most votes. The Australian government itself is First Past Post but as you mentioned it doesn't have Plurality it has Instant Runoff. Although I would say First Past Post is just as bad as Plurality as it only counts a select majority and not the whole country, another alternative is Multi Member Proportional like we have here in Aotearoa, or Proportional Representation like in Denmark. Multi Member Proportional means any party that exceeds a certain amount of votes will win the election (the limit is 5% here in Aotearoa), however they will only have a certain amount of seats in government proportional to the amount of votes they get, Proportional is similar however it limits it has to met before getting into government.

Given that there is an actual good reason we have the electoral college for presidential elections, it'd be interesting to explore favourable alternative voting systems that preserve the asymmetry of the EC but resolve the spoiler effect.

Here's something interesting: Instant runoff reliably makes the worst candidate lose, but could cause a runoff conflict because it sometimes removes the strongest candidate first. This is what creates the center squeeze, and would lead to more extreme positions. However, seeing that the correct loser is reliably identified makes me think that with some slight tweaking, we can identify the correct winner.
Instead of eliminating the lowest first choice vote-getter, we can instead eliminate the highest last-choice vote getter. This avoids eliminating the centrist early. Using the instant-runoff example with this method eliminates green immediately, then orange wins the runoff with pink.
I would refer to this as "reverse instant runoff." Of course, any blank entry by a candidate should count as a "last choice." Taking that into consideration, I can't find an obvious flaw with this method, aside from it being slightly unintuitive.

7:19 on the centre squeeze. Ok so Queensland Australia held its state election on Saturday. Probably the most recent example of what you’re talking about. We have two major parties, the LNP which is broadly economically and socially conservative, emphasis on regional and rural areas. The other is the Labor Party, traditionally the left-wing workers party. But in some areas third parties have big enough support to win seats.

In the inner city seats of the capital city, Brisbane, the Greens have increasing support. This election they gained an extra seat. The Labor party is being squeezed in these seats.

Something you didn’t touch on is that the other two parties are able to maximise the benefit they receive from this.

We have how to vote cards. Voters can obviously go in and chose what order they would like to rank the candidates in. However, if they chose to vote for a party or even a well organised independent candidate, they will usually follow that candidates how to vote card. It tells them what order of preferences would be most reflective of that party / independents position, or sometimes, most strategically beneficial.

So the LNP who despise Greens policy, chose to preference the greens over Labor. In fact they preferences the greens second in these seats, and even preferenced Labor last.

In a close inner city seat where the fight is between the two left wing parties, the LNP are able to swing the seat based on their preference flows, not based on ideology, but on strategy.

It’s pretty interesting. Most people I guess don’t care. But to me what someone does with their how to vote is something I would consider before voting for them, and definitely before I follow that card. We have a far right nationalist party called One Nation here, there is a billionaire who was buying up millions of dollars of advertising but had no real policy and was lying about the policies of the government. There is an anti-vaccine party, and many independents of varying suitability. So for me, when the LNP puts Labor past, I can see no good justification for that. Same applies if Labor were to put the LNP last on their how to vote.

Here in France, we also have a Plurality voting, but a candidate can only win the election by getting over 50% of the votes. If no candidate has that much votes, we do a second round with only the 2 top candidates from the previous round. If the scenario at 03:37 took place in France, Green would not actually win the vote, instead Purple would be ruled out (because they have the least vote), and a second round would take place between Orange and Green; thus just like 03:14, Orange would still be winning.
(Although, it's a very good solution for 3 candidates, it's still not perfect still doesn't work so well with 4 or more candidates, which we often have.)

All this to say: It feels natural to me to vote multiple times instead of just once, and it would be worth simulating how multiple rounds would work with the other voting systems, most notably Approval voting.
Let's assume a first round with a small dozen of candidates, and a mandatory second round that would only take the top 2, 3 or maybe even 4 candidates from the previous round. I believe this would encourage voters to vote "honestly" in the first round, and then to "betray" (or rather, in this context, "refine") their votes in the second round; the Chicken Dilemma could become less of a dilemma and more of a natural part of the voting process.

Ultimately, I assume the fairest voting system would have almost as many rounds as candidates, only ruling out one candidate per round, but I don't think it's realistic to expect people to go out to vote this many times.
Instant run-off is interesting on that point; because I don't see why people would change their ranking in-between round (unless their actual opinion change), it's a system that has the potential to be done in a single round and still be fair. (Though I personally think having at least two rounds should remain mandatory regardless, to account for human error from the voters. Having flashbacks from the 2002 French Elections here...) The real question is how we should interpret the votes in such a system; in your video you take the first choices and rule out the ones with the least vote, but what would happen if, for example, you took the last choice of each voter and ruled this one out instead?

The problem is simple for America: Do away with the Electoral College, it does NOT work for a democracy. Each vote should count EQUALLY. Secondly, assign seats based on votes for ALL parties. It is never perfect, but it is far better than what the US currently has.

In Canada we have 5 federal parties (only 4 of which actually have meaningful support) and we break the country up into small regions based on population, then run 338 mini plurality elections in each one. The winner of each mini election then occupies 1 seat in parliament. If one party wins more than 170 seats, they have a majority government and can pass any legislation. If no party wins more than 170 seats, then we either have a minority government formed between a coalition of parties that together possess more than 170 seats, or if no parties can agree to a coalition that has more than 170 seats, we have another election (which essentially never happens).  What this does is guarantee that every federal party has to run everywhere in the country if they want to form government. It also means all of our regions have a local representative at the federal level, and produces stable governments. But what also happens is the winner of the "popular vote" across the country often doesn't actually win the election which bothers people. Or with the multi party system, the government is lead by a party that only actually received support in the 30's. And it's also open to the strategic voting phenomenon of trying to hurt your biggest opponent instead of voting for who you want. There's good stuff and bad stuff with every system. And just because a system works in one country doesn't mean it will work in a different country with different regional dynamics.

Yet they get to pass on the the second round of voting. Which gives us an "ok candidate" and a "nononono candidate".

This happened twice in a row (maybe more) in France with a kind of scary xenophobe party (called FN) getting to the second round. Of course, on the final round, we get (normally) 74%, 26%. But it's a waste of time and shines a light on a marginal party that shouldn't be talked about. Making it more appealing for the next time.

I have an idea that I think would be better than all three of these systems. Each voter gets (let's say) 10 votes, which they may distribute among all of the candidates as they wish, except that they cannot give more than (say) 7 votes to any one candidate. Most voters would give 7 votes to their favored candidate, and 3 to a second "acceptable" candidate, if one exists. Your "baseline" is a race between orange and green - but orange only wins because you're not including purple. When you change the number of candidates, you change the entire election. In Sweden we have kindof a mix of plurality and Instant runoff in the sense that you vote for one but we have at this point 8 parties that share the parlament slots. As long as you get 4% or more of the total votes you're in. To actually win the election though the parties form alliances post voting so that they together form the government or approve of one of those alliances. So right now we have 2 parties represented in our government approved by 3 other parties that are not included but prefer their ruling to the other alliance that is further on the right wing. So the voters can never truly be sure what kind of government they vote for. Although we usually get a pretty good sense of what alliances can occur based on the values the parties represent. But I really find the system to be very flexible and pro democracy with minor parties being able to grow in influence. We actually used to have more like a two party system but over time so many minor ones have gained traction. This has the pros of the parties never taking their slot in politics for granted and therefore not becoming 2 sides of the same coin but rather focus on building their own core values and foundations. But it might be cause I don't live in the US but I feel I would have a much harder time there to find an option that feels great and on the most part always voting for the lesser of two evils.

How about a model of an issue by issue based pure democracy, without elected candidates? Seems better, as none of the winning candidates had true majority approval in these 3 systems at all. Maybe they'd win with 55% but only because there were really only 2 options, and 20 of the 55% only voted for the winner so that they'd be on the winning team. Take out the representative, and the line model works perfectly, with blobs that fall on one side voting no, the ones on the other side voting yes, and in the middle 3rd, blobs that are allowed to not have a voice on this one issue, but still have a voice for other issues. If you vote for a candidate to represent you on all issues, then issue by issue, you only end up with assumed pink, or green blobs. The problem with these models is that as they are representative systems, so you always have every blob on the map, even if in reality a blob doesn't care about apples, mangos, or home architecture in the slightest. If you ONLY vote on issues that concern YOU, a third category voter emerges. One that isnt forced to be represented as a pink blob, or green blob, issue by issue, when really they aren't... the indifferent blobs, the grey blobs. In a truly democratic system, if 10 out of 100 blobs voted option 1, 70 didn't care, and 20 voted for option 2, option 2 wins. Lets say the same approval rating of voters exists in a plurality representative system for a single issue, 10%apples, 20%mangos, 70%indifferent. Now let's say that the whole apples or mangos thing never came up once during the election process, but now, mid term, the elected representative has to decide which. We never talked about invading Afghanistan before electing the representatives that made the decision to for example, as there was no reason to discuss invading a country that we haven't perceived as attacking us. Why would it possibly have come up in the election. So the representative has little to no knowledge of what the overall approval of the populace is on the issue, and he/she now has to make a decision. Now let's say that the 10%apples crowd, and another 50% of total voters who were indifferent to apples, and mangos but loved the "whole kiwis are better than cherries" stance that the representative took during election, and he/she was elected 60% to 40%, then now, percieved as nothing more than winner kiwis, and loser cherries, no one in the populace has any voice at all on the apples to mangos issue. The representative decides to go with apples, and now you have twice as many sad blobs as happy ones. 10%winner apples, 70%individuals, and 20% disenfranchised pro mango voters. The plurality representative system only works if you have a party for both sides of each issue facing blob-kind. A party that is solely pro apple, and also has no opinion on the housing, and one that is pro mango that also doesn't care about the housing. You'd also need a pro apples, and spooky house party, a pro apples and nice house party, a pro mango,and pro spooky house party, so on and so forth into infinity. That's the only way you'd never be forced to have your vote go to a party that doesn't  align with you on any given topic in a representative system. Or we could represent ourselves like individual humans, and not livestock. Then again we can't represent ourselves right now unless through private enterprise inside the system, or a bloddy rebellion that no one wants.
One thing the left, the center, and the right can agree on is that we need a better voting system.

In Brazil, exactly the "Center Squeeze" happened in the 2018 elections. Here is not exactly an Instant runoff, but it is similar, the two candidates with the most votes in a first round of elections go to a second round (if none has more than 50% of votes), there aren't several voting rounds where only the last ones are eliminated. What happened in 2018 was that Bolsonaro was strong because he was right-wing against a left-wing party that ruled the country in recent years and displeased many Brazilians. Still, Bolsonaro had a very strong rejection. In the elections he went to the second round with Haddad, from the left-wing party, and won by having a minor rejection. However, had Haddad not been the second most voted but some other candidate outside that left party, Bolsonaro probably would have lost, due to the number of people who voted for him just to not have that party in government again

Two party dominance happens because people don't want to vote third party. They always vote lesser of two evils.

Last estimate I saw was from 2016, where 30% of voters for both major parties only voted for their candidate because they were the lesser of two evils.

That's a total of 38,651,542 votes. Add that to the 4,489,341 votes the Libertarian candidate received and suddenly the message has been sent that two party dominance is over. Also, in October 2016 there were 203,000,000 registered voters, but only 136,669,276 votes were cast. If 10% of those uncast votes went on top of the 30% from each party, Gary Johnson would have been the president.

So please, everyone, STOP voting for the lesser of two evils and don't be afraid to vote third party. Both current dominators were once fringe third parties.

I just thought of a voting system that someone else may have invented elsewhere but which I will assume here: Run a simulation with the following rule: a vote equals (a - b +1)/a. where a equals the number of candidates and b equals the rank order, assume that the rank order of all unranked candidates is equal to the lowest ranked choice plus 1. So A voter voting for Green with no preference for Orange or Purple will be counted as: 1 vote Green, 2/3 vote Orange, 2/3 vote Purple. A voter voting for Green over Purple over Orange would be counted as: 1 vote Green, 2/3 vote Purple, 1/3 vote Orange. This system solves The Chicken Dilemma by forcing you to make a choice in order to disempower your least favorite rival.

Simplifying the political landscape to a line; if the 2 major parties start near the centre they both earn half the votes. If a third party appears on either end of the spectrum, in an ‘extreme’ position, this threatens the votes of the nearest central party. The rational move for the threatened central party is to move their position towards the extreme. In the end both major parties are forced to move to ‘extreme’ political positions in order to secure their flanks. Centrists avoid creating a centrist party because this risks an extreme party on the opposite end of the spectrum getting into power, the ‘spoiler effect’ as you mentioned. You could probably find examples of this in real life.

The other thing about this is that it assumes static "values" of the candidates.
In addition to the effect of the voting system, the third-party voting issue also has an effect on the party values.

For example, Australia used to have traditionally a two-party system roughly equivalent to the US, with one conservative and one liberal party. With the addition of minor parties, which almost always carry some extreme values, it gradually pushes the values of the two main parties closer to the middle to try and take a larger chunk of the central voters.
So what was seen in Australia was with the Greens becoming more successful (left, environmentalist party) it pushed ALP (left, worker's rights/education/infrastructure) further into the centre and closer to the LNP (right, religious conservative/business/anti-diversification). This means that the presence of an unsuccessful greens party (assuming most primary greens votes then go to ALP), the middle-left people now have a choice of voting for someone who won't win, or for someone who no longer supports them on the issues they are interested in, whereas if the greens weren't there, then the ALP would be able to campaign further to the left to ensure that they engage those far left voters.

In Australia, we now have a variety of far-right parties now, which again, can make those voters quite upset when their candidates have very little political clout, or it can have the opposite effect when both major parties earn a minority of seats each, which gives these small minor parties the "deciding vote" on everything, giving them a disproportionate amount of power.

Some interesting stuff happens with systems like Canada's. Each district (much smaller than most states) runs MPs, and the winner of each district gets a seat. The party with the most seats wins and their party leader becomes the Prime Minister.

For who becomes Prime Minister, it comes down to 2 parties because of things mentioned, like strategic voting, but because it's easier for a smaller population of voters, like in a district, to agree on a minority party, a lot of seats actually go to parties (or independent candidates) besides the 2 main ones. This means there's not a guarantee of the PM's party having a majority of seats. The first time Justin Trudeau was elected, he actually won a majority, but the latest election he was re-elected with only a minority government, which requires more cooperation and compromise with other parties to pass bills, as the elected MPs are the ones who vote on those. "First past the post" makes more sense when "the post" is something like needing at least 35% of the vote, instead of an absolute majority.

Locally, strategic voting may differ from nationally. For example, my district historically elects either a Conservative or NDP candidate. Voting Liberal, even though Liberal nationally is the only contender to Conservatives, poses the same issue of splitting the vote, and just makes it more likely for Conservatives to get another seat. So if you'd prefer either Liberal or NDP over Conservative, it's more strategic to vote NDP, and this gives minority parties seats to advocate their position and vote on bills and gain support, without getting butted out of the government altogether just because they won't get PM. It does require districts giving new candidates a chance though, and risking that they won't be successful and the seat will end up going to an undesired candidate.

I think you've made one assumption that makes this analysis not work so well. Most of the time votes are cast to determine the distribution of seats in a democratic body (like a house, senate, parliament, etc.). For this you don't need a "winner". The point of the voting system is to allocate seats relative to how people vote, not determine one person who wins overall. I live in a country with direct proportional voting system (where % of the popular vote directly translates to % of seats). The "winner" is just the largest political party at the end, but due to this system it will be very likely they will not have a majority. The largest party not having a majority means they are forced to work together with other political parties to form a government. This means that voters can vote for the party that best suits them and even if they only get a small number of votes, it is guaranteed they still get represented and their party might even become part of the coalition government, even if not that many people voted for them. No vote is wasted.

P.S. the first past the post system refers to picking representatives through small local elections and sending that representative to parliament. While in a proportional vote system you just tally up all the votes in the country and allocate seats based on the national vote. First past the post system leads to a 2-party system quickly since the 'winner' in the local election becomes the representative, which means all of the votes for smaller parties do not get taken into account on the national level.

One thing you have to take into account in many systems is coalitions. Let's take the example of Germany, the one I know best, because I am German: There are six political parties that have a realistic chance to make the parliament: Die LINKE (left-winged socialist-leaning), SPD (social democrats), Bündnis '90/Die Grünen (the green party, somehow leftist and ecology-centered), FDP (liberal, a little to the right and economy-centered), CDU/CSU (conservative, also called "the Union", because it's actually two parties, but CSU only exists in Bavaria, CDU in the rest of Germany) and AfD (right winged, partially to the point of being extremist). The SPD and CDU/CSU are the dominant political parties with no other party ever providing the chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany (FDR) since its foundation in 1949.
First of all: There's no "winner takes all", unlike in the USA. If a party scores more than 5% of the votes overall, they are eligible for the federal parliament. The number of seats they get roughly corresponds with their percentage, when all parties with less than 5% are left out of the picture. Until today there was no case that any of the two dominant parties had an absolute majority (over 50% of all seats). So, to form a government, they have to collaborate with each other, compromising their goals into a contract that somehow fits both partners. Usually the Union wants to coalate with FDP and SPD wants to coalate with Grüne. But if they don't get a majority of seats, they cannot form a stable government.
So when you, for example, want to vote Grüne, but don't want the CDU to take power, you can still vote your favourite party, because they would - if possible - coalate with the SPD. But at the moment, the Union is the strongest party and that would not change if you either voted green, SPD, LINKE or any other of the six big parties. As long as there's enough people who vote CDU/CSU.

What if we voted on a policy and not a person?
1) At the beginning everyone writes down the percent of budget they want spent on a sector (e.g education, healthcare, etc)
We take the average of the values
2) People then write down the main ways they want to spend that sector's budget (e.g with $10 in education, lets hire $5 worth of teachers)
3) People finally vote on a person to execute this budget
If the person fails, we replace with a diff person . the president's only role is to execute the budget that the people voted for, and has no say of their own to change it.

Issues that don't relate to budget (e.g abortion, gun control) would just be solved by voting for the policy that they like. Experts could still advise how to spend the budget in a 'democrat' or 'republican' way but now the people get to choose how they wanna run the country instead of choosing between two other plans. This also gets rid of the 'I don't like either candidate' problem.

Score Then Automatic Runoff (STAR) Voting is a pretty good system. It avoids the middle squeeze and doesn't punish honest voting or promote strategic voting. It would take up to 75% of strategic voting to have an effect on results.  You give candidates a score of 0 to 5. The two with the top scores go to the runoff round. The candidate you give more points to become a vote for that candidate. If you give an equal score to each (something you can't do in most voting systems, expressing indifference), then you are counted as abstained.

Could you assess an alternative ranked voting system to the instant runoff that potentially avoids the "center squeeze" phenomenon? It would be a ranked voting system where voters would rank all of the candidates. Except instead of having the candidates with the most "first choice" votes stay in the race and eliminate the last place, it would give a 'weight' to each vote. The first place votes have the most 'weight' to them, the second place votes have the second most 'weight' to them and so on. The candidate with the most weight of votes would win. For example one way you could do this weighting process is if there are 10 candidates, a first choice vote would give that candidate 10 points, a second choice vote would give that candidate 9 points and so on until the 10th choice vote gives the candidate 1 point. The candidate with the most points would win.  That way it's the most like a compromise. Hypothetically if in this political compass grid there is a straight line drawn between candidates (as is displayed in the "center squeeze" scenario) and two extremes love their extreme candidate and hate the opposite extreme candidate but both would rather have the middle candidate over the opposite extreme then that would technically be the "most agreed upon candidate"

You did not do very well on your research for examples of approval voting. The United Nations currently uses Approval Voting to elect its secretary general. China's National People's Congress (NPC), the largest Parliament body in the world, has been elected via, essentially, Approval Voting since 1979. The Greek parliament was elected by means of Approval Voting during 1864-1926 with which they replaced their previous SMP system.
Approval voting was widely used with introducing democracy in the Soviet Union started by M.S. Gorbachev. The Catholic Popes were elected via approval voting in 1294-1621, but with revotes and extra nominations until somebody attained 2/3 supermajority approval level.

A few years ago there was a voting in my city (São Paulo, Brazil) to vote for mayor. Here, our system is kind of like the instant runoff system, but with only two stages (sometimes just one).
If candidate A gets over 51% of the votes (I think), they instantly win, but if that dosen't happen, the two candidates with most votes goes for the second stage, and that's it.
Living under this system we spotted a few problems with it, being some of them mentioned on the video.
Anyway, all of this to say that, in that time, me and my friend ran over some calculations (by hand), and we thought that the best system would be the scoring system, which could be extremely good in situations in which there are three main candidates, being two of them more in the extremes of the political espectrum, while the third would be more moderate. If I recall well, we calculated that, in our current system, one of the two candidates from the extreme would win, but in a score system the more moderate one would have better chances, and would probably represent better the whole of the voters

I would suggest that the 'flaw' of instant runoff isn't a flaw with instant runoff. It reveals another flaw with 2party voting. Consider this: A centrist shouldn't get an overwhelming majority of votes simply because there is no else who better represents their side of the issues to vote for. 2party voting creates a situation where a lot of people are voting for a candidate that is actually very far from what they want, but is the only candidate that supports their issue at all (Orange, 6:32) . If there were better options that were closer to representing the views of each person, they would vote for that option instead (as in 7:24). Joe Biden is this kind of 2-party spoiler. Many people who vote for him think he is 'weak' at defending their viewpoints - but they feel they just don't have another choice. Instant runoff lets them pick a candidate that represents their views better, by comparison. After loosing, Oranges voters still count, and can still pick the remaining candidate closest to their viewpoints. The result: The candidate whose views are closest to the largest number of people than any other candidate, is the one who is picked.

Here in the Netherlands we have a different voting system.
There a total of 150 seats to be given away to different parties. Each party gets a number of seats based on the number of votes they have. Say that 10.5mil people vote in the election, every 70,000 votes grants the party 1 seat. After all the seats have been distributed the biggest parties then have to form a coalition to have at least 76 seats between them.
But here is the tricky part. It is not like the top 4 parties just gets grouped up and call it day. No. The parties gets to decide who they want to work with. So after all the seats have been assigned, it can sometimes take weeks or months before they get a number of parties who want to work together who also have the mayority (76+) of the seats.

The good thing about this system is that everyone gets to vote for their favorite.
Bad thing is that the coalition can sometimes be made up of parties that don't work well together.

Fun fact: Approval rating is the voting system of choice in most of the marxist-leninist socialist countries such as the Soviet Union, Cuba, and even modern China. This is why often they would get ballots with only one candidate on them. The point wasn't that you only had one choice, the point was to measure approval. In most cases, if the single candidate did not have SUPERMAJORITY approval, they would be recalled, and a new election would have to be called with new candidates selected from the voter base. This method of approving one candidate at a time and allowing immediate recall avoids the Chicken Dilemma while maintaining a government with high approval ratings.

To fix the centre-squeeze you can just change the voter threshold.

This applies to voting in one electorate*
Imagine 5 parties all with primary votes and secondary votes and tertiary votes that work as the following:
Far Laft: Primary Vote: 2% Secondary Vote: 1%
Left: Primary Vote: 40% Secondary Vote: 11%
Centre: Primary Vote: 18% Secondary Vote: 60%
Right: Primary Vote: 36% Secondary Vote: 13%
Far Right: Primary Vote: 4% Secondary Vote: 15%

Under a First-Past-The-Post system, the Left party wins. with 40% of the vote.

Now, let's imagine a preferential voting system where only the two largest parties remain and everyone else's votes are redistributed:
Left: 40%+11% = 51%
Right: 36%+13% = 49%
Left party wins again.

Finally let's imagine a system with a 15% voter threshold, meaning if a party has over 15% of the vote, they are not removed in the fist round of voting...
Left: 40%+2% = 42%
Centre: 18%
Right: 36%+4% = 40%

Now, what happens if we rearrange the votes between these parties Based on secondary votes?
Left gets 42% + 9% from the Centre Party,
Right gets 40% + 9% from the Centre Party
But Centre gets 18% + 82% from both of the other parties.

Under this system, 82% of voters prefer the Centre-Party over the party on the other side of the spectrum, thus the centre party wins every election...

But yeah, I think this is a terrible idea. I prefer the two voting systems Australia has. Because this Centre-squeeze effect doesn't even happen in Australia. The major parties in Australia are Centre-Left and Centre-Right.

The true problem with any voting system is the existence of political parties.
Too often, people are voting for their favorite party and not necessarily for the actual candidate.
The other problem with parties is that they are only representing their party and NOT the people they are actually being elected to govern.
It gives people the false illusion that there are only two choices because these are the two parties in control.
In a country the size of the United States, where we all can't even agree on our style of pizza, what makes you think that a Democrat from New York and one from California are the same party with the exact same belief? What about a Republican from Texas and one from Florida or Idaho are the same thing? No, they will never be the same, but because of the two party system, these people are homogenized and in the end the parties only say what they know will get them elected. The individual candidates fall in line with party leadership to keep the party strong so they can all win elections together.
In the end, they aren't actually representing their constituents and what the constituents want.
The president basically will do anything for their party while shutting down the opposition without so much as a thought.
Very little gets done because the voting in Congress is predictably down the aisle as it were, and unless one side holds a super majority, or slants the few independent representatives to their side, all they do is butt heads on who is right. Very few people are ever willing to cross the aisle in fear of repercussion from the party heads so that they can maintain the connections they have when their re-election comes up.
If we eliminated political parties, we'd have representatives that not only actually represent the concerns of their constituents, but would be more willing to compromise and negotiate with each other regardless of affiliation, and come to legislative conclusions that are more palatable and fair to a larger swath of the country as a whole. It would feel like a whole country is getting a voice instead of just the half that picked your party. Not to mention that, in the US, the two major parties don't even truly represent half the voters. Only about 1/3 of all registered voters actually are registered for either major party. This means that no matter which party is in control, about 2/3 of all voters have no true voice.

As a firm believer in IRV/preferential voting, I would like to point out that the scenario that you described for green winning was only an issue if you were a purple voter, if you were an orange voter preferrencing green, you still got what you wanted, your second choice, and the whole point of preferential voting is that if your candidate doesn't win, you get your second choice applies. The other feature of preferential voting, which you might see as a bug or a feature depending on your views, is that often parties will make "preference deals" where they agree to suggest to their voters to vote #2 to another party in exchange for some alteration in policy. This means that more minor parties may still have some influence on the government even if they actually don't have enough of the vote to get into parliament. This doesn't exist in the approval voting method you describe, since due to the 'chicken' scenario there is no incentive for parties/candidates to collaborate,

I think that if Canada kept their system of governance but paired it with proportional representation as opposed to first past the post, we'd have a pretty good system. In Canada we don't vote for a Prime Minister, we vote to elect an MP for our constituency. Provinces are granted constituencies based on population. For each constituency won by a party, said party is granted a seat in the House of Commons. The party with the most seats will become the leading party and have its leader be the Prime Minister. The second largest party will become the official opposition. Having a system of governance like this means that even though one party is the leader, the other parties have a say and can represent their voters interests. This is taken to an even greater extent if the leading party fails to take a majority government, meaning they dont get at least 50% of the seats. But I imagine you can already see the problem, our system is still flawed, just on a multitude of smaller scales. Although Canada has many parties, most of which see some marginal success like the bloc de quebecois and the NDP, there are still two major parties. The Liberal and Progressive Conservative parties. Meaning that we still experience the problems of plurality, once again, on many smaller scales. Proportional representation would do away with the constituencies completely, and instead you would simply vote on who you want to win. Seats would be awarded based on the percentage of the population that voted for your party. If 36% of the population voted for your party, you'd get 36% of the seats. Parties that wouldn't even win a single seat with first past the post would win seats with proportional representation. You'd be encouraged to vote truthfully, even if your favourite party is a lesser one. Because with this system, they are ensured to gain at least some say in the governance of the country. And their say would be proportional to the amount of people who wanted them. This is still plurality, as you are simply voting for who you want to win. First past the post and plurality are different things, they aren't synonyms. At least not by the definitions in relation to Canadas government. Plurality would be the method by which you go about voting within a first past the post or proportional representation system of election. I dont think plurality is what the problem is, it is the system of governance. And I just realized this probably falls under the multiple winner thing you mentioned and it was a moot point bringing it up as it was technically irrelevant.

Edit: This system still wouldn't be perfect, the biggest flaw I noticed was the question of who will fill the seats in the house of commons. If you aren't voting directly for each individual MP, then how will they be chosen? Of course we could keep our first past the post system of election and instead do away with plurality. Utilizing on of the two other methods of voting listed, but as you said, those aren't perfect either. Politics are a tricky thing.

Australian here to simp for preference voting (aka. ranked choice). I think the usage of only 3 "parties" maybe obscures the way this tends to work in practice, with there being many candidates (>6 in most cases) on the ballots for lower house elections, with 2 major parties typically preferred to win. This means that the "Betray the favourite" effect comes down to putting one of the 2 major parties above the other and then voting for minor parties as desired. This gives a good ability to communicate through the vote even without getting an independent/3rd party elected (a small candidate receiving many 1st preferences is a notable thing to larger parties), with the effect flipping if enough people desire a small party over larger ones.

This is by far the most flawed logic on YouTube. All of these systems end in a single party winning, a party with direct opinions. It is a fact that a party, especially one that represents the broad opinion on a topic and therefore is more likely to gain the support of the people, will take a general stance on said issue, such as yes or no. For practical reasons, and the fact that people would still have to make a SINGLE decision on which groups would represent them in the executive, people begun to side with a single group, and a clear divide developed between the groups on the opinions that were, for the most part, opposite. A single winner takes all system ensure that the MAXIMUM amount of people have their voices heard. In summary the nature of issues themselves leads to a two party, winner-takes-all system, where most people feel most represented. This is more directly proven by the fact that parties CHANGE. They either change with their stances or they get removed from the primaries completely, to best represent the majority of peoples opinions summed up in a single party.

In a point based system, Green has 114 points, Orange has 87 points, and Purple has 99 points, but that's only counting first place votes, now if we add in second place, Green has 142 points, Orange has 229 points, and Purple has 129 points.
Now add in third place votes.
Green has 175 points, Orange has 229 points, and Purple has 167 points.

In this system, you completely reverse the Centre Squeeze. You end up with a candidate that in all forms would be the ultimate compromise in beliefs, Orange voters would be happy their candidate won. Purple and Green voters would be happy the other didn't win.

And if you give the option for people to simply not vote at all for parties they don't like, effectively giving 0 points like in the Approval system, you still don't have voting strategists breaking things. For instance if they were Purple and thought "okay so I need to just not put Orange as my second place vote...." Nope, they failed. They simply make it easier for Green to win. They could always vote 1st place on Purple and leave it at that, but then they risk Orange not making it into office, and thus Green might make it into office.

This system would promote the most innoffensive parties every. Centrist parties. Parties that only work towards progress and stability.

Here in Brazil we have a "two turns" system for the Executive Power.

For example: this year, we have the municipal elections, so we'll vote for mayor and city councillors.

For mayors, in the first turn, we have all candidates, from all parties. Then, we vote honestly, based on our beliefs and political ideologies. The two most voted candidates go to a second turn.

Then, in the second turn, we vote between only two candidates. That's the strategic vote.

This system is used for the State and Federal elections too.

For the legislative election, we have another system, that's actually very complex and not so ethical...

In Australia it is not called instant runoff and we don’t hold a series of elections to whittle down the list of candidates. It is called preferential voting where you number every candidate in order of preference. The candidate with the lowest vote is eliminated and those votes are redistributed amongst the remaining candidates based on the second preference on those ballots. This process continues until there are only two candidates remaining and thereby one will have at least 50%+1 of the vote - an absolute majority.

A few years ago I worked out a score voting system, based on the Dutch government structure. I found it very appealing for countries with 5+ up to dozens of parties, and even works up to thousands, although the number of points and votes might need to be tuned.
For ~12 parties, I simulated it like this. As a voter you get a set of 4 scores:
You get one 3-point vote.
You get two 1-point votes.
You get one minus-1 point vote.
You can only hand out one score per party, but you don't have to spend all of your scores.

It's a very interesting way to use the outcome of polls that are honest in the issues. The minus-one vote puts a serious damper on populism and lowers the chance of polarizing parties on the more extreme ends of the political spectrum to win.

One potential flaw is that voters don't necessarily vote for parties based on a list of issues, but have other, more abstract preferences, such as upbringing, family / social aspects, or even a specific leader's amount of charisma or ability to debate or give speeches. This is very difficult to simulate without running large-scale polls.

Unfortunately, one of the more serious flaws with small scale simulating this system turned out to be not so much the voter strategy or the system flaws, but the way parties present themselves in the actual issues. A big risk exists by parties having a stronger "sales pitch"-campaign. The government lacks a governing body above the government that enforces the promises politicians made in their campaign.

That's a very big fundamental problem that no voting system in itself can fix. How do you hold parties or individual politicians accountable for their campaign promises?
One direction is to capture the mandate that the voters give the parties in a set of laws, but in practice, this is very hard to enforce.

This video is misleading and disappointing as I would think the narrator would instinctively understand that the world is much more nuanced than simple simulations from what I've seen in his other videos. First, humans are experts at gaming the system and have devised ways to overcome the spoiler effect in plurality voting systems. I would be interested in modeling voting districts and the ability to move between them. Second, there are democratic governments around the world that have a proliferation of parties with constant changes of power (e.g. Italy), and it is hard to argue that these systems are better than two party systems with the constant power flip flops. Therefore, while the video is indeed educational in simulating simple voting systems, it strays pretty far from political science theory at the end..

Okay, so what if we used the approval system, but instead of giving one vote per candidate, we had a fixed number of points we could assign to each candidate?
So if I really liked Yellow and thought green was okay too, instead of giving a vote to yellow and a vote to green, I could give ten points to yellow (my maximum) and eight points to green.
This would eliminate the chicken dilemma because if I wanted to push support toward a more-favored candidate I don't have to eliminate support from a less-favored one. Having a third-favored candidate win in this scenario would be effectively impossible, and having votes shift toward one candidate between two closely-matched candidates would only be the results of whom people actually favor.

Another problem with rank off is that if the two big parties are your favourite, you must put the most favourite at the top and the second one at the bottom since oyherwise you would give extra votes to the other party

This also happens with approval metod, you approve both orange and green (the big parties) and both are verh close to each other,, you can only approve your favourite or you will also give votes to the other party

It's also worth noting that these problems aren't actually fixable. Arrow's Impossibility Theorem is a mathematical proof that shows why a perfect system that always maps varying individual preferences to a group consensus can't exist. It's not an unsolved problem waiting for mathematicians to work on, it's actually impossible.

The problem with the Center Squeeze example is that it requires having more knowledge of the votes of others than you can possibly have while voting.  Situations where it breaks are really contrived.  Possible, but anyone planning on it happening is being foolish.

The problem with your portrayal of Plurality voting is that it uses the American standard, which means you have two dominating parties with one or two smaller parties that get shafted because of the 'winner takes all'-system for deciding the winner in a county/state.

Whereas with the Dutch system, which has roughly 40-ish parties you can vote for, and a direct representation-based system (the total votes for a certain party from over the entire country determine the number of seats in parliament they get) results in a situation where a lot of different views can be represented because they will be directly represented. We currently have 16 parties in our parliament , with the 6th largest ones having between 14 and 32 seats each, with a total of 118 out of 150 available seats. This means it's quite difficult to have one party dominating parliament, because you will need to make agreements with other parties to pass bills and make decisions. It also means you don't (necessarily) have two big, important parties that squeeze out the others.

There's also something to be said about political psychology based on the voting system that's in place. I feel that the more time passes by, the less nuanced politics and people's political views in general become. A plurality voting system essentially forces each voter to "pick a side", whether they agree with only one candidate or not. This can lead to a lot of the mudslinging and political bigotry that we have today. If you support the Democrats, Republicans will condemn  you, and if you support Republicans, Democrats will also condemn you. I feel it causes people to reflect less on why they're voting for whom they are and rely solely on the instinct that they're more closely affiliated with a certain political party, so they should just vote for that party, regardless of the candidate.

I think the german voting system is doing a good job at minimising flaws.

You can vote for one party like in the plurality system. After that, members of the parliament are distributed proportionally to the amount of votes they recieved.
You win the election not by getting the most votes as a single party, BUT the key part is that you win by getting 50% of the votes total.

In theory, you could win this vote by getting more than 50%, but this doesn't happen. That's because this system eliminates the spoiler effect. You can get 50% by forming a coalition with like-minded parties. And the head of the party with the most votes gets to be the president here, which isn't that much of a president but much more like a representative. NOW purple and yellow in the example given (3:36) could form a coalition without purple unintentionally screwing yellow, no spoiler effetct. Many decisions by the parliament are decided by what decision gets 50% of the members of parliament's votes.

Now, for other important issues you will need 2/3 of all votes, which can only be achieved when the opposition is somewhat in favor of the decision as well so they get those 2/3rds of the votes. This can only be achieved when the interests of 2/3rds of the parties are satisfied and you come to the best compromise for all parties. This is also a good opportunity for good politicians to have influence even though they don't make up 50% of all representatives.

the problem with ranked voting (and why most countries even those who use them didn't start with them.) is that they eliminate the center faster. In a ranked voting system it pays to make your candidates as extreme along your measured line as possible without getting farther away from the center than your foe so that you still win when the centrist is eliminated and can pick up the voters on the extremes. with plurality systems, both candidates are encouraged to run as close to the middle as possible so as to ensure the other candidate doesn't take the center and win automatically. this also has the handy effect of traping extremist ideology on the fringe rather than elevating it to prominence. and preventing majorities electing horrible extremes was one of the key concerns of early democracies. plurality makes valleys in the electorate harder to maintain (though not impossible as we can see today) the larger the valley gets between your choices the more tempting entering the valley becomes for both candidates. In ranked-choice, this is not the case. you need a giant valley for the center to win and making the valley bigger is incentivized by both outside parties to draw in the extreme flanks and maximize participation. only once that valley starts winning will the sides move in. then you end up with a mountain from which the center will rule and the parties play king of the hill.
until of course, one side of the line manages to move the center. If the center goes left or right (on your line) not by the parties moving but by the line shifting then you need redo your system again as rushing to the extreme and activating non-participants becomes more palatable to the loser of that shift than running to the new center and it has a chance of moving the line back as well as the box of acceptable expands. the new center also becomes harder to eliminate because the side that lost ground is now further away than before(hence why many countries switch from plurality to ranked after massive landslides or long periods of single-party rule, America is actually kind of unique in not doing so despite longterm republican rule after the civil war. then the democrats ran to the far left activating socialists of both national and revolutionary varieties from Wilson to FDR and into the cold war which in turn shifted the line underneath them back again. now republicans are trying the same trick since they lost their opportunity to lock in advantage with ranked voting only with extreme individualists instead of extreme communalists.)
plurality promotes centrism and unity as a clear majority is needed to win, though this breaks down if less than half your electorate is participating (hence modern-day America until trump less than 50 percent of the electorate voted in more than a decade) ranked-choice promotes extremism and subdivision of the electerate where no one likes the winner because very few people ever voted for the winner as their first choice. this happens a lot once you go beyond 3 participants and the system actively encourages people to put forward their favorite flavor rather than settle for good. the ranked-choice system often makes perfect the enemy of the good over time.
approval is super rare because even though it has far fewer disadvantages it looks more like cheating to the observer. it is no longer 1 person one vote but instead 1 person however many votes they want (even if they cant double vote for the same person which you never actually specified. not being specific about this could lead to saying a person choosing their favorite multiple times and make the strategy problem worse.) The approval also encourages people who would vote for no one to interfere with the process rather than place forward a candidate of their own as no candidate they propose can ever weaken another candidate.

Approval voting has one fatal flaw: Party can split to two different parties. Imagine you have 2 parties on the opposite side of the spectrum, both with 50 approval votes, so they each get 50% seats.
Now let's say party A splits into two parties A1 and A2. Each will get all approval votes as would original party. So now 3 parties has each 50 approval votes, meaning each party will get 33.3% of seats. But two parties are basically the same, they will most likely opt to cooperate. So one side of political spectrum stole seats from the other.

The main reason two party systems are so popular that I can tell, is that at least they get a majority vote, or close to it. In a straight forward democracy, if candidate A gets more votes than candidate B, A wins. If there’s 2 candidates, A is going to get over 50% of the votes guaranteed. Aka MOST of the voters got what they voted for. In a system with many semi equal parties, we can have candidates winning with a shocking minority of votes. If we have say 5 candidates from different parties that are on somewhat equal footing, we may have a winner that only got 25-30% of all the votes. Meaning ~70% of voter did not get what they wanted.

This is not as much a problem in representative democracies (republics), but can be quite a big issue in other systems.

First past the post, while usually a subset of plurality voting, is not interchangeable.

First past the post indicates a minimum vote requirement (hence the 'first candidate to receive X votes/delegates/etc" being the comparison to horse racing) and is usually part of a majority vote system (a subset of plurality voting in which not only must you gain more votes than anyone else, but a minimum of 50% + 1 as well).

There is a problem with approval voting, and that is, you can't really as a voter, use any opinion-based system to "calculate" what you should vote, since you need a good threshold of where you should approve or not (as the circles shown). And then it starts getting too complicated.

Imagine you put in that you like Mangos and Modern houses, it could then "calculate" which party or candidate you should vote on. In a plurality or ranked system, you just pick the best party, or pick the list of party the system gives you when you have inputted your opninions.

A voting system must be easy for citizens to understand and make use of. It must be easy and unabmigious to translate "I like mangos and modern houses" to an actual vote. Or in the real world - if I say "I want to increase gas tax for the enviroment, I want to require schools to return unused money instead of pocketing it, I want to make it easier for courts to prosecute people" - then this can translate to a specific party, whose is "closest to me" and then a list can be built, a list that is completely objective, which I could just copy to my ballot.

When in approval system, you need some sort of threshold system which makes it subjective. When should you approve? Approve the top half and leave the bottom half? Approve the 3 best candidates? Approve everyone which scores more than 50% of my opinions? Etc. It makes the voting system waayy too complicated.

The best voting system ever, is to just have yes/no questions for all individual decisions. Throw out the government, and let the people vote completely. "Increase gas tax? Yes/no". "Lower the threshold for evidence being accepted in court (at the cost of judgning some innocent guilty) - yes/no" etc etc. It makes it super easy for people to vote, and with a digital system you could easily have running polls/vote every day, where people only vote on the topics they are interested in.

A clear, and badly flawed, model. It ignores the fact that democratic procedures have more purposes than just finding the maximum preference among candidates. They also have the purpose of fostering the discussion and aggregation process that enables society to figure out its concerns, priorities, candidates, and choices. The discussion and aggregation is in reality the heart of the democratic process; the voting is the icing on the cake.
Most political science has concluded that, in most cases, plurality voting and two-party is the system most often good at fostering in-depth discussion, compromise, and aggregation. Plenty of times it does poorly at that, but other systems do even more poorly at it. This, for civic minded people who want their society to work well, would outweigh its greater technical imprecisions in measuring voter preference after the discussion and aggregation have been concluded.
It also tells us that plurality voting often actually works better for measuring actual preference, despite technical appearances to the contrary, because it fosters aggregation processes that define issues, candidates, and preferences more subtly and usefully than the other systems do.
The other systems enable our ideological passions to be better fulfilled in having multiple parties expounding detailed ideological platforms for us to listen to and vote for. It's only our passion to make our society work well that suffers from them.

The problem is not the plurality vote but the majority voting system, where the party with the most votes wins the district and therefore just the biggest parties can get a seat in the parliament. In most european countries for example, we have only one vote, but it is paired with a proportional voting system, where the party gets as many seats as the percentage of votes they got. For example, the Libertarian Party got like (might be wrong here) 3% of the votes in the US in 2016, so in a 100 people parliament they would get 3 seats in a proportional voting system, whereas in the majority voting system they got 0 because they didn't have the majority in any district. Most european countries that use that system have 5 - 10 prominent parties instead of two as a result of that

In Germany everyone has two votes. One is about the candidates of the voting district. The winner is send directly to the Bundestag, the equivalent of the House of Representatives I guess. The other vote is about the proportions of every party that should be represented in the Bundestag. One half are the direct mandates, the other half are chosen based on the percentages of every party on their lists.
There are some absolutely stupid rules that are making the Bundestag just to big (the prognosis says we will have over 1000 mandates next election), where the major problem is that the number of mandates gets adjusted by every „state“ by his own.
But besides of that, I think the baseline idea is a great system. You have the proportion of every prefered party represented and the preferences of each place. And it doesn’t lead to a one party system. Parties have to form coalitions and make compromises to lead.
