I would like to point out that any, more complicated voting system, absolutely requires that voters are not only educated on where they stand on each and every issue but also on the issue of every single candidate. And this is where analysis of different voting systems fail, the real world isn't perfect. The US is a representative voting system. In the early days this meant you selected electors that would go on to pick a candidate that they believed would be a best fit for your state. With states attempts to gain more power that shifted into a system of semi-direct democracy which shifted the country from a true "Any Party" system to a "Two Party" or plurality voting system. But back to the original point, no voter will be 100% educated on every possible policy or policy initiative, or candidate, or possibly won't even care about certain things, so by increasing our variable space for this is unnecessary and becomes an educational exercise more than a realistic possibility. Instead we can investigate why, even in these other systems, two party outcomes are still the most likely. And this comes down to preferences and not policy. Lets say that individual i chooses not to educate on candidates or precedent or past government policy and chooses to vote for the person they believe will react in similar ways to them, how most people globally vote. If the candidate is not lying about their position or fundamental beliefs then individual i has not reason not to trust that those reactions will be mostly in line with their own. This is a drastic simplification to the problem. Individual i will then believe in general that either more government, less government, or no change is the appropriate solution to the current major issues they care about or just in general. With this philosophy of voting a natural minimization problem is set up at each election. This minimization forces candidates to minimize the distance to the majority of voters until what we see today GLOBALLY is that candidates either generally fall in the category of increased government intervention or decreased government intervention with several key topics being the focus of most voters decision making. Jumping to the US election and party's specifically, The republicans and "conservatives" in general believe less intervention is needed and democrats and "liberals" believe more government is necessary in general with independents and other third party's either having generally more extreme views or just falling in between the candidates. Now if any government on earth was set up to be run by a single human and all approvals would go through that single human, yes a multi party system or more importantly a system where peoples favorite candidates are given votes in a way that isn't parasitic to others would be best. But with these large complex bodies of individuals, the party's are more as what I described being "Guidelines" for voters to get a feel about the general leanings of the party and each election gives them an opportunity to deliver specific information on various topics. A political party and politicians in general are very dishonest and implementing a system where literally trillions of possible policy combinations are possible it forces both the voter and the politician to do things that are physically impossible. And I mean impossible based on actual physics. The universe is not old enough to simply state all the combinations much less study and understand the intricacies of each. On top of that 2020 highlights immensely the importance of selecting a candidate who is going to instinctively act as you want them to act and not have a pre-planned response. If you believe in times of economic crisis the governments role should be to provide aid, relief, and support to individuals, and intimately interact with regulation to improve the situation then vote for someone who in general believes that. If you believe that in times of emergency the government should let go of the reigns and allow individuals to handle it then vote for someone who believes that. Complicating an optimization problem only ever makes it more difficult to solve not easier. It makes it take longer to solve. We need to work on simplifying the problem not complicating it.

The big shortcoming of the US is that only one candidate can win. Most countries have a parliament in which politicians are distributed in percentages. So the party with 30% also gets 30% of the seats, the party with 26% gets 26% of the seats, the party with 22% gets 22% of the seats, etc. There is no reason for a single winner (except for something like a head of state, which should not have much more power than other parliamentarians, but is just the head, because it is good to have one person at the top, so that other countries have a single person as a contact person who then represents the parliament, but it's not really relevant from what party that person is, as his job is to represent all parties).

Weighted score voting is the best. Especially if the range changes based on the number of candidates. The power of the voter changes based on the field. It benefits honesty. It properly reflects voter preference. It lowers the bar of entry for a newcomer candidate or party. And while the most popular "first choice" won't necessarily win, it does pick the optimally favorite from the largest percentage of the population.

The best example: each candidate receives points based on this equation: C - R , where C is the number of candidates and R is the rank. Any positive number gets added to a candidates total. Let's say there are 5 candidates. You only like 2 of them. You rank Candidate A: 1, Candidate B: 2. And you leave the rest blank. Candidate A gets 4 points (i.e. 5 - 1) , candidate 2 gets 3 points (i.e. 5 - 2). The rest get zero.

Someone else might wish to choose for only one candidate. Another person wants to rank them all. Every voter's true preference for each candidate is reflected in the final tally.

Honestly, I consider all of these systems so deeply flawed (approval probably being least bad, since at worst it's FPTP) that I hope any electoral reform rejects them out of hand (STAR would be my choice, but there are others I could live with). That being said, there is a way to eliminate the Center Squeeze of IRV, and given IRV's prevalence in election reform discussion, I hope this modification gains ground: essentially, rather than eliminate the lowest ranked candidate, you do a head-to-head runoff of the two lowest ranked candidates, then eliminate the loser between the two. This, somewhat sneakily turns it from true IRV to a condorcet method with extra steps (condorcet being one of the "others I could live with" mentioned above), but I think, while it's not the ideal cycle-resolving method, and worse than STAR, IMO, it's the easiest to introduce to an IRV-dominated discussion on election reforms, by bringing up the center squeeze phenomenon and positing it as a solution, without having to bring up more complicated electoral science topics.

I see a larger problem with instant runoff than plurality. Plurality essentially makes it a 2 person race, but once that is taken care of then those 2 people are incentivized to move their opinions closer to each other to get more votes. If you have every vote to your left/right no matter what then you want to move closer towards the center to make the least number of people mad at you. Instant runoff on the other hand directly hurts the person in the center who would have won in a plurality system. The approval method seems like the best option since you get the person most approved of overall ignoring who the other people are, it can lead to unfortunate mind games, but that's the fault of people trying too hard than the system itself.

A real world example similar to approval voting:
Lots of parties have, in internal elections, so called "slate voting": e.g. if there is a body with 10 members and 15 candidates for the body, an elector can vote for 5 to 10 candidates, and the 10 with the most votes get a seat. This means an elector has to face a trade-off between voting for the top 10 candidates they like (being honest) or "undervoting", voting only for the candidates they really like, to make sure they get in. Now, this is a multi person election, but in the case where there are n+1 candidates for n positions, it is equivalent to approval voting: only that you are voting against the single person you don't want rather than the single person you do, and everyone you don't vote for, you "approve" of them losing. In my (anecdotal) experience, people tend to undervote, making sure a smaller group of people they like don't lose. This would be the equivalent of (in approval voting), approving multiple candidates, to make sure someone you really don't want to doesn't win.

As an Australian, I don't think I've ever actually seen the Centre Squeeze effect play out.

Typically our centre party is in the top two of pretty much every district. There's only a couple of exceptions I know to this. While it is possible that this effect could play out when the Greens leapfrog over Labor, all the evidence I've seen from recent elections suggests that at least in inner city districts there's a very tight flow of preferences between the two parties to the exclusion of the Liberals.

What does actually happen here is a form of party lead strategic voting, where in seats where the three parties are pretty close the furthest right party often tells voters to vote for the furthest left party second rather than the centre party. This is actually how the Greens initially won their first seat. The Liberals told their voters in central Melbourne, a seat where they stood no chance to preference the Greens ahead of Labor. They did. The Greens have controlled this seat for 3 cycles now, they don't need preferences anymore though.

I disagree with your criticisms of approval voting. They stem from 3 bad assumptions.
1: That all voters have a universal approval 'radius'
2: Voters don't have a preference order
3. Any change in your vote is a tactical vote. (tactical votes are votes that don't represent your true preference)

In the first case where there are blobs that approve/disapprove of all 3. Even though they might think all 3 are acceptable or none are acceptable, they still have a preference where A > B > C Then giving a vote of approval to A and B is not a tactical vote. It is a truthful vote that expresses their desires more accurately than the vote of A, B, and C. Similarly for those that don't really like any of them. They will have a least disliked candidate. And in the unlikely event they have truly no preference, there is no goal for them to aim for, so tactical voting is impossible for them.

In the second case, you bring up. What the blobs are doing is choosing the radius of acceptable candidates. Which is entirely in the prerogative to do, again it's not a tactical choice because if they prefer A>B>C voting for only A is not a tactical vote, it is still a truthful vote. Voting for [A,C] [B,C] [B] or [C] would be tactical votes, but they are all going to be worse votes for you to cast. Unless you have really good reason to believe that the race is only between A and B, but in which case why vote for C at all?

And the 'chicken dilemma' becomes even less of an issue with more candidates, which is the ENTIRE reason to do an approval voting system in the first place.

If there are more candidates and you prefer B > H > E > Q > S > Z > N > Y > J > X And you choose to vote for only B, that is still a truthful vote you are a super 'picky' voter, that's willing to discard the rest of you ability to influence the decision. But if you say you want to 'hedge your bet' by also voting for Z who seems to be a crowd favorite that you think has a better chance of winning. There is no reason not to also vote for S, because if Z ends up winning, you'd have been better off voting for S, and if S ends up winning you'd have been better also voting for Q, And so forth up the chain.

So yes there is a minimum threshold you have to pick, but once you pick the minimum you're willing to work with, you're better off picked everyone else above it. Unless you already know what everyone else is voting, but then you also have no reason not to vote for the true preference that expresses your preference.

Also one really nice thing about approval over rank choice. It's super simple to implement, you don't have to worry about the confusion between ranking orders and giving points/scores, you are always encouraged to give a truthful preference, especially since most people aren't that likely to play chicken with their own favorite candidates, and more likely to do it with the candidates they are less likely to prefer. And a benefit that is rarely brought up. Given that people's preferences are nowhere near that organized across all issues, it makes it so that two candidates that seem very similar to one set of voters, are actually very different to another set of voters, which is where you'll get better decisions made from people who can see how the candidates are different than how they are the same. So sure you'll still get the 70% of the voters who just vote straight down a party line, checking all the Ds or Rs as if that began to approach their civic duty to vote. But then the people who are more likely to evaluate the candidates more critically will be able to serve better as tiebreakers.

Now as to why no government has it. Well, it's quite simple, politicians hate it. They'd much rather let the party have more control over the candidates that are on the ballot, so they can force us into ever-increasing no-win scenarios which are far more exploitable for political gain. (Maybe a tad to cynical, but not by much)

And they you have the german voting system. Which combines First-Past-The-Post and percentage. So you have to votes: one direct vote and an indirect vote. Your direct vote votes for a regional candidate for your election district, the winning candidate gets a seat in the Bundestag. Your second vote is for a party, the percentage of votes a party gets, determine their percentage of seats in the Bundestag. Well, partially. Now we get the political fuckery: If a party has more direct mandates (by winning voting districts) than seats they should get based on their percentage, they just get the direct seats. This lead to the two biggest parties frequently having a higher percentage of seats than they should have. This was now remedied a little in recent years.
The interesting result is, although a party needs to have only 5% of votes or 3 direct mandates to join the Bundestag and therefore there are multiple parties in the Bundestag, technically two parties always could have formed the german government. It's called a Große Koalition (Great Coalition) or Schwarz-Rot, Black-Red, based on the party colors Black for the Christian Democratic Union/ Christian Social Union which are more or less the same party and Red for the Sozialdemokratische Arbeiterpartei Deutschlands [SPD] (Socialdemocratic workers Party of Germany).

So even with multiple winners you can get a two party system in which two parties could always rule and the other parties would always play opposition. This hasn't happened that often though, since for the two big parties CDU and SPD it's much better to have a smaller party to get them to over 50%, since their coalition partners almost always plummet in the votes afterwards.

A few years ago we had an interesting situation during the vote for president in Austria.
To make it simple: We have multiple parties (at that point two big ones, three medium ones) and each one nominated a candidate (or at least supported one).
Usually noone would get above 50% during the first election, so the two most popular ones would go into a second election, usually of course the two candidates by the two big parties.

This time it was different.
For some reason the two candidates by the two big parties were really unpopular.
Of the other three parties, one was quite far on the left, one quite far on the right and one in the middle while being somewhat liberal.
Due to the polls everyone knew what the situation was, so the candidates on the far left and right received most of the votes, because they were afraid of the other extreme.
Meaning the middle candidate did not get into the final election, even though EVERYONE knew, that she would win, if she was set up in an election against anyone else.

No system is perfect I guess.

Example: lets say their are two people voting purple who prefer yellow as their second but they absolutely do not want green to win. So instead they put their first vote for yellow

Purple: 5 - 2 = 3
Yellow: 3 + 2 = 5
Green: 5

Now yellow gets into round 2 not purple. this means it's 5 v 5 plus 3 votes from purple need to be distributed. Because, it's purples second vote they are alot more likely to vote yellow for their second not green.

Yellow: 5 + 3 = 8
Green: 5

In this scenario changing your preferred first pick. Can change the winner to one you desire. So if your purple in this case its better to vote for yellow unless you are confident purple will win in a landslide.

Personally, I like the idea of a hybrid Approval-Runoff system. I've heard it referred to as "Ranked Plurality" before, but I that seems to mostly just lead to Instant Runoff/Ranked Choice when I try to google it.

In any case, the idea is that it's a graded approval system like was mentioned in the video but not explored/simulated where the grading scale is the number of candidates. In an election with three candidates, your first choice would be 3, second choice 2, and third choice 1, or alternatively 2, 1, 0. And then whoever has the highest score wins.

Applying this to the first Instant Runoff example, assuming honesty, we'd end up with...
Purple voters: Purple - 54 (18 * 3), Orange - 36 (18 * 2), Green - 18 (18 * 1)
Orange voters: Purple - 78 (39 * 2), Orange - 117 (39 * 3), Green - 39 (39 * 1)
Green voters: Purple - 43 (43 * 1), Orange - 86 (43 * 2), Green - 129 (43 * 3)
Total: Purple - 175, Orange - 239, Green - 186

So Orange wins, just as with regular Instant Runoff. And if we then apply to the center squeeze example...
Purple voters: Purple - 99 (33 * 3), Orange - 66 (33 * 2), Green - 33 (33 * 1)
Orange voters: Purple - 44 ((15 * 2) + (14 * 1)), Orange - 87 (29 * 3), Green - 43 ((15 * 1) + (14 * 2))
Green voters: Purple - 38 (38 * 1), Orange - 76 (38 * 2), Green - 114 (38 * 3)
Total: Purple - 181, Orange - 229, Green - 190

Orange still wins, and the center remains unsqueezed! The winner should in theory always be whoever is the least objectionable to the most people, thus avoiding situations where a majority really DON'T want a certain candidate, but can't unite behind a different one, so the worst candidate wins anyway. And I can't really think of a way to strategically manipulate this system either.

Another idea for a voting system: Ranked Approval

What if we did a ranked vote and then added the total place # of each candidate together (first choice gets 1 point, second gets 2, and so on) and then whoever has the lowest score wins? It would be immune to the spoiler effect for the same reason as instant runoff, it would avoid center squeeze because there would be no threat of it being eliminated like in instant runoff, and the chicken dilemma would still slightly maybe slightly apply, but to a much smaller degree considering that one could still support their preferred party while giving their secondary preference support to a smaller degree. The chicken dilemma would not be completely removed here, but its effect would be vastly mitigated due to the ability to weight your approval towards your preferred candidate.

Thank you for this video - It's very well produced, and clearly made with passion and care. That being said, there are a couple of things I things I think you could have handled better relating to your tone and message. For one, you largely fail to acknowledge the impact that replacing plurality voting - which, although flawed, is the simplest and clearest form of voting - will have on voter confidence. Communication to people about how their vote is counting is important, and I feel like that value is being understated here. Secondly, you made some very broad statements (you heavily imply that plurality voting is *clearly* the worst option). You make several assumptions in order to reach this conclusion, most of which I think would be better off left to the viewer to make if they so wish. I don't even necessarily disagree with you - I just prefer that in future videos, you present the simulations without such heavy-handed commentary and allow viewers to draw their own conclusions.

Once again I want to emphasize that this was all just some constructive criticism. I'm a huge fan of your channel and your work. Stay well!

You neglected to mention the main benefit of Plurality Voting, and why it's so popular from a voter's perspective.

Obviously from a candidate's perspective, it's best because it doesn't challenge the two party status quo, but for a voter, consider that by definition roughly half of the population is of below average intelligence. Plurality Voting is mechanically simple to understand and (things like the electoral college notwithstanding) it's simple to follow its cause and effect. Plus, you just have to make a single vote, essentially between only two people. And for this reason, they're also simpler from a backend perspective. You just count votes.

The more complicated (even if strategically perfect) voting systems will always have the downside of needing to still be accessible to the general population, as well as requiring more complex calculations to tally.

I know this video made things purposefully abstract, but I couldn’t help but apply a real world scenario to these voting systems.

So with the approval system for example, if I am extremely far left I might only truly approve of Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren. However, if I’m determined to unseat Donald Trump at any cost then I might be willing to expand my range of approval to be Pete Buttigieg and Joe Biden purely out of fear.

So I’m wondering if that could be considered a flaw of the approval system. If someone is scared a particular outcome, they might be forced to expand their range of approval in order to avoid a certain outcome. However the ranked choice voting system doesn’t have this problem, because the voter can always value their choices in a more stepwise manner than simply a binary “yes or no” vote.

So as you mentioned at the end I think being able to assign a numerical value to the approval system would probably be best.

Ranked voting is OK, but instant runoff voting just sucks. I don't know why nearly every system of ranked voting uses this when it is so stupid. For example, in Burlington Vermont in 2009, this idiotic system did not give Andy Montroll the victory. Why does Andy deserve the victory? In that election, he was preferred over both other candidates (which we can tell by looking at the ballot results since they are ranked). In other words, in any 1 vs 1 election against any other candidate, he would win. No rock-paper-scissors ambiguity that sometimes might arise. if there is no circular preference, of course that guy should win. But ISR didn't give him the win. You know what would be better? Look at how each candidate and give them a score of how much they lose to each other candidate, or give them a zero if they in fact beat them. Then pick whoever has the lowest score. If any candidate beat all the others, he would score 0 in all contests. Is that still too complicated for people? Fine, how about a round-robin tournament where every candidate is pitted against another and earns a point for beating a different candidate. If you're going to let the guy who is preferred over all other candidates lose, you might as well not even have a ranked ballot since you're not even using the ranking properly anyways.

I think more people should look into Schulze method. It allows you to rank candidates however you like -- some can have equal ranks and you can leave some completely unranked -- which makes it inherently resilient to error.

It satisfies Condorcet, it's monotonic (unlike IRV -- the flaw that is demonstrated here is its non-monotonicity), it's computationally less expensive than IRV. Both IRV and Schulze fail the participation criterion, but this can be addressed with compulsory voting -- Australia has compulsory voting, not explicitly for this purpose, but it helps.

The Approval System WAS USED in local elections in Bavaria this year. You get a vote for every council member(city, county, village, etc.), which can get to more than 100 votes.
- 3 votes maximum per candidate -> 0,1,2 or 3 votes
- you can tick a party list, which equally distributes your votes for that party - more or less votes for one candidate is still possible
- you can freely choose your candidates from whatever party lists, e.g. 3 votes for M.S(CSU), 2 votes for A.M.(SPD), 3 votes for Hans(Mango-Party).
- you are allowed to use all votes, but you can use less if you want

Plus, tactical voting isn't really a thing in any German election, apart for the 5% barrier(because the CDU/CSU NEVER loses). 7 parties(CDU/CSU,SPD,FDP,B90,AfD,Die Linke) have seats in the Bundestag. All except the AfD are part of a German state government.

What about Condorcet voting? Basically, instant runoff, but every candidate runs against every other candidate one on one, no matter what (so in practice, it's just more computations, but doesn't require extra effort from the voters). The winner is the candidate that wins against everybody else. But, you could say, what about cycles, like in rock, paper, scissors? Well, first, this is extremely unlikely, and second, if it happens, it means the candidates are in a sense equivalent and the tie gets broken by picking one of the winners at random, or, more likely, running the election a second time.

What if the U.S. voting system (or any voting system for that matter) started out with a plurality vote, and any candidate who received at least 1% of all votes was then put into an elimination vote? Say 6 people ended up getting over 1% of the plurality vote. Among those 6, the citizens would do an approval vote of who they absolutely do NOT want the president to be. Then, from the remaining 5, they'd do the same thing until they end up with 1 candidate left.

Let's say there are 1000 people in a society. 600 of them are voting for the left, and 400 are voting for the right. Let's say there's some divisive issue among the left, so the left has two candidates with 300 each, while the right has only 1 candidate with 400. This system would allow the two groups of 300 on the left to come together into 600 vote out the 400 on the right. After the right candidate is removed, those 400 who supported him could then input their say on which of the left candidates is better (or worse technically). This way, the people would be properly represented as the majority of people were on the left and the left won, but it would also give everyone an opportunity to have a both meaningful and honest vote.

I was in France in 2002 when something very strange happened: the worst candidate (a racist, sexist, isolationist clown) arrived at the final round, leaving the other guy to win in a slam dunk.

What happened? Well, the French use a two round system where the top two candidates are selected first, then the voters vote again from the top two. The top two candidates were Jacques Chirac and Lionel Jospin. Everyone assumed these two would make it to the final round. But see, at the time, French voters were dissatisfied with their choices, but blank votes were not counted.

Enter Jean-Marie Le Pen, who advocated women to stay in the kitchen, for immigrants to be kicked out, for imports to all stop and for France to revert to its old currency (seriously, I randomly picked up a brochure). Lots of French voters decided to vote for this clown as a joke, in a form of protest vote.

Except, Lionel Jospin's votes were diluted because the several parties on his side of the politics failed to rally under him.

Jean-Marie Le Pen got to the second round. Everybody went 'oh shit.' Jospin and his supporters all loudly called on voters to vote for Chirac, because at least he's not That terrible, and that's how Chirac entered the second round with some of the historically worst rates, and won the final round with the best rate.

Even so, at least Le Pen did not get voted, so I suppose this pales in comparison to the strangeness of Trump being elected the president of the world's #1 superpower.

The election of the executive branch: "Mayors, Governors and President" might have two "turns".
In the first turn, we can vote in any candidate, so usually there are about 5 to 10 candidates for each position.
If one candidate gets more than 50% of the votes, it is considered elected, if not there is the second turn.
The second turn occurs some few days after the first turn. In this turn just the two most voted candidates can dispute, and then the most voted one gets elected.
So in many elections, there is the strategy from the third place in the pools tries to get voters from the second place to vote on him, so he can have a chance in the second turn.

What about a sort of "reverse runoff", where voters vote for their least favorite candidate who the gets eliminated? The voters would still rank the candidates from most to least favorite, but the one who has the most "least favorite" votes gets eliminated instead of the one with the least "most favorite" votes like in traditional runoff voting.

I have written algorithms to simulate plurality, runoff and reverse runoff voting and had the following results:

To get a controlled environment I placed 100 voters in a 10x10 grid, evenly spaced in the unit square.
I placed 3 candidates ai the locations (0.4 | 0.4), (0.55 | 0.55) and (0.65 | 0.65).
Plurality voting with only the first two candidates results in a 45 - 55 result, so candidate 2 wins.
Plurality voting with all candidates results in a 45 - 27 - 28 result, so candidate 3 wins.

In a runoff voting, the first round ends in 45 - 27 - 28 again, so candidate 2 gets eliminated.
In the second round the voting ends in 55 - 45, so candidate 1 wins the vote.
This is what you described as the problem with this voting method, candidate 1 wins even though candidate 2 is a better candidate than candidate 1.

Now for my proposal, reverse runoff voting, where the least favorite candidate gets voted out:
The first round results in 45 - 0 - 55; the voters either dislike candidate 1 or 3, but do not want to eliminate candidate 2. Candidate 3 gets eliminated.
The second round results in 55 - 45, meaning most voters dislike candidate 1 more than 2, so candidate 2 wins the vote.

This method appears to favor centrist candidates over the border candidates, and I'd like to see your thoughts on this (I mean all of you).

Edit: I've done some more research into this: I created a metric to measure voter satisfaction, this is based on the distance a voter has from the candidate. The distance is squared, the average from all voters is taken and then inverted (I have also tried this with the raw distance without squaring, but it did not seem to make a difference). The higher that number the more satisfied the voters are. This metric may have its flaws, but i just went with it for a lack of better ideas.
Anyway, the result I found is the following: The average satisfaction for plurality is the lowest, followed by the average satisfaction for instant runoff. My proposed reverse runoff has the highest average satisfaction, but only by a small margin. The code I used for this was added in the code block below.

For the interested of you, here's the js code I used for the simulation:

//code start
var voters;
var candidates = [[0.4,0.4],[0.55,0.55],[0.65,0.65]];
//This function randomly distributes voters in the unit square.
function generateVoters(amount = 100){
voters = new Array(amount);
for(var i = 0; i < voters.length; i++){
voters[i] = [Math.random(),Math.random()];
}
}

//This function generates a number of candidates, randomly distributed in the unit square.
function generateCandidates(candidateCount = 3){
candidates = new Array(candidateCount);
for(var i = 0; i < candidates.length; i++){
candidates[i] = [Math.random(),Math.random()];
}
}

//This function evenly distributes voters in the unit square.
function generateVoterGrid(gridSize = 10){
voters = new Array(gridSize*gridSize);
var gridOffs = 1/(gridSize*2);
for(var i = 0; i < voters.length; i++){
voters[i] = [(i%gridSize)/gridSize+gridOffs, Math.floor(i/gridSize)/gridSize+gridOffs];
}
}

//a untility function
function sqrDistance(A, B){
var dx = A[0]-B[0];
var dy = A[1]-B[1];
return dx*dx+dy*dy;
}

//This function simulates the plurality voting method
function plurality(candidateCount = candidates.length, printResult = true){
var votes = new Array(candidateCount);
for(var i = 0; i < votes.length; i++){
votes[i] = 0;
}
for(var i = 0; i < voters.length; i++){
var fav = 0;
var favDist = sqrDistance(candidates[0], voters[i]);
for(var j = 1; j < candidateCount; j++){
var d = sqrDistance(candidates[j], voters[i]);
if(d < favDist){
fav = j;
favDist = d;
}
}
votes[fav]++;
}
var win = 0;
var winVot = votes[0];
for(var i = 1; i < votes.length; i++){
if(votes[i] > winVot){
win = i;
winVot = votes[i];
}
}
if(printResult){
console.log("Candidate " + (win+1) + " won with " + winVot + " votes.");
console.log(votes);
}
return win;
}

//This function simulates the runoff voting method as described in the video
function runoff(candidateCount = candidates.length, printResult = true){
var roundCandidates = new Array(candidateCount);
for(var i = 0; i < roundCandidates.length; i++){
roundCandidates[i] = i;
}
do{
var votes = new Array(roundCandidates.length);
for(var i = 0; i < votes.length; i++){
votes[i] = 0;
}
for(var i = 0; i < voters.length; i++){
var fav = 0;
var favDist = sqrDistance(candidates[roundCandidates[0]], voters[i]);
for(var j = 1; j < roundCandidates.length; j++){
var d = sqrDistance(candidates[roundCandidates[j]], voters[i]);
if(d < favDist){
fav = j;
favDist = d;
}
}
votes[fav]++;
}
var loss = 0;
var lossVot = votes[0];
for(var i = 1; i < votes.length; i++){
if(votes[i] < lossVot){
loss = i;
lossVot = votes[i];
}
}
if(printResult){
console.log("Candidate " + (roundCandidates[loss]+1) + " was eliminated.");
console.log(votes);
}
roundCandidates.splice(loss, 1);
}while(roundCandidates.length > 1);

if(printResult) console.log("Candidate " + (roundCandidates[0]+1) + " won the runoff.");
return roundCandidates[0];
}

//This function simulates the reverse runoff voting method as described in my comment
function reverseRunoff(candidateCount = candidates.length, printResult = true){
var roundCandidates = new Array(candidateCount);
for(var i = 0; i < roundCandidates.length; i++){
roundCandidates[i] = i;
}
do{
var votes = new Array(roundCandidates.length);
for(var i = 0; i < votes.length; i++){
votes[i] = 0;
}
for(var i = 0; i < voters.length; i++){
var fav = 0;
var favDist = sqrDistance(candidates[roundCandidates[0]], voters[i]);
for(var j = 1; j < roundCandidates.length; j++){
var d = sqrDistance(candidates[roundCandidates[j]], voters[i]);
if(d > favDist){
fav = j;
favDist = d;
}
}
votes[fav]++;
}
var loss = 0;
var lossVot = votes[0];
for(var i = 1; i < votes.length; i++){
if(votes[i] > lossVot){
loss = i;
lossVot = votes[i];
}
}
if(printResult){
console.log("Candidate " + (roundCandidates[loss]+1) + " was eliminated.");
console.log(votes);
}
roundCandidates.splice(loss, 1);
}while(roundCandidates.length > 1);

if(printResult) console.log("Candidate " + (roundCandidates[0]+1) + " won the runoff.");
return roundCandidates[0];
}

//This function returns the average satisfaction of the voters with a given result. The average satisfaction is the inverse of the average of squared distances from voter to result candidate.
function getResultSatisfaction(result){
var satisfaction = 0;
for(var i = 0; i < voters.length; i++){
satisfaction += sqrDistance(voters[i],candidates[result]);
}
satisfaction = voters.length/satisfaction;
return satisfaction;
}

//This function simulates a given number of votes and prints the average satisfaction for each of the three voting methods.
function simulateVotes(count = 100, candidateCount = 3){
var pluralitySatisfaction = 0;
var runoffSatisfaction = 0;
var reverseRunoffSatisfaction = 0;
for(var i = 0; i < count; i++){
generateCandidates(candidateCount);
generateVoters();
pluralitySatisfaction += getResultSatisfaction(plurality(candidateCount, false));
runoffSatisfaction += getResultSatisfaction(runoff(candidateCount, false));
reverseRunoffSatisfaction += getResultSatisfaction(reverseRunoff(candidateCount, false));
}
pluralitySatisfaction /= count;
runoffSatisfaction /= count;
reverseRunoffSatisfaction /= count;
console.log("Average plurality satisfaction: " + pluralitySatisfaction);
console.log("Average runoff satisfaction: " + runoffSatisfaction);
console.log("Average reverse runoff satisfaction: " + reverseRunoffSatisfaction);
}

plurality();
console.log("Runoff");
runoff();
console.log("Reverse Runoff");
reverseRunoff();

console.log("100 simulations");
simulateVotes();

Best compromise is IRV but modified so that instead of continuing until only two candidates are left, it only eliminates candidates until there is one that would beats every other candidate in a 1v1 runoff (which in 95% of real-world elections means you just find the clear winner immediately, but if there's a rock-paper-scissors tie between three candidates you just use IRV to determine who to remove).

That's called Benham's method, and it's generally very good at eliminating the main drawback of IRV (the center squeeze), while keeping its main strength (mostly no Chicken dilemma). Also, in the vast majority of elections where there is a clear winner, it tends to significantly speed up the process of finding that winner, so it's also better logistically.

I’ve pondered a score voting system too, where you are required to vote for every candidate, but in the order of preference.

For example, in a race of five candidates, you list your votes in order of preference, so your first choice would get 10 points, your second choice would get 5, and your third fourth and fifth choice would get 3, 2, and 1 points respectively.

Instead of tallying single votes, you would tally the total scores received from all the votes, and the one with the most points wins. This system would allow third parties to receive adequate representation without majorly altering the outcome of the race. I haven’t looked into possible drawbacks of this yet, but the only thing I can tell is likely a similar squeeze effect as the Instant Runoff system.

There's another system that is by far superior to all others.
Direct Democracy, where you vote in a party/leader that you trust would make the right choices in matters you don't care or know enough about while also having a distinct YES/NO voting power on every issue in politics.

Say your favorite candidate loves apples and modern houses but wants to make applesauce out of every single apple which you do not approve of. You can still vote for that candidate because he/she will make lots of apples and modern houses but when the issue on whether all apples should become applesauce you can still vote NO on that one thing, while leaving all other decisions up to the candidate you like.

That's how direct democracy works. You have a voice ALWAYS, not just on election day. If you don't care about how the apples are handled, you can simply refrain from voting and the candidate will vote in your place.

First past the post: as opposed to proportional systems: if there's two parties for 4 seats and one party gets 75% of votes with the other party 25% of votes, the first party gets all 4 seats, as opposed to a proportional system where the first gets 3 seats and the other 1.  The first past the post takes all.  This makes it almost impossible to have more than 2 parties.

The big problem with plurality voting is that it suffers from Hotelling's problem: Parties are incentivized to move closer together to catch more of the middle ground voters. Thus you end with with parties that are barely different from one another.

Instant runoff has the opposite problem that it prefers extremist parties since mode moderate parties would suffer from middle squeeze.

Another voting system that is my personal favorite is Ranked Pairs voting.

Voters rank candidates like in Instant Runoff, but the winner is chosen differently. The ranks are used to compare candidates to each other in every possible 1v1 pair.
If any candidate beats every other candidate in the 1v1 pair, that candidate wins.
Otherwise, you rank the pairs by the percentage of votes the winning candidate was ranked higher than the losing candidate of the pair. Then you go down the list and whenever you reach a candidate that would create a cycle (think rock beats scissors beats paper beats rock), you ignore the pair where the winning candidate won by the lowest percentage.

So as a quick example, take an election where A beats B in 70% of votes, B beats C in 60% of votes, but C beats A in 51% of votes. You ignore the (C,A) pair and that makes A the winner since they win in all their remaining pairs.

I must comment on the Australian way of voting because I'm an Aussie who loves this kind of topic. 1: Ranked-choice voting is only mandatory for state and Federal elections, councils (local municipalities) can choose what style of voting system they use (the majority of councils use Ranked-choice, but some just use the plurality style of voting).

2: Ranked-choice voting in Australian elections has lead to something called preference deals, where different political parties strike a deal and tell the party they are making a deal with that they will tell their voter base to preference them.
For example, Party A and Party B have decided to do a preference deal, so Party A will inform its voter base to give their 2nd preference to Party B, and Party B will inform its voter base to give their 2nd preference to Party A. It should be noted that while different political parties can tell their voters who to preference, the voters are not mandated to follow those requests.

For a real-life example, the state of Queensland in Australia has just had its state elections. The Greens party of Queensland lost primary votes (first-choice votes), but they still managed to win a seat off the current state government because of the preference choices (2nd and third-choice votes). It should also be noted that mini plurality style voting can happen when only 2 political parties are running in a particular electoral seat. This primarily occurs because the bigger, more well-established parties have greater resources than smaller parties, so the bigger parties can afford to put candidates forward for more seats, smaller parties find this difficult to do.

Now for some interesting Queensland voting facts. The state can essentially be split among three primary voting areas; Northern Queensland, Central Queensland and South East Queensland. Northern Queensland is mostly small and medium towns with mining and agriculture making up a large part of that area's income, Central Queensland is similar, but with fewer and smaller towns, with mining and agriculture making up the majority of that area's income. South East Queensland has the capital city of the state, Brisbane, is the most densely populated part of the state, and gains more money from services and finance.

The current controlling party, the Labor party, has managed quite a feat in the election just passed and has electoral seats from across the state. The current opposition party, the LNP, primarily holds the regional seats that have a heavy reliance on mining and agriculture, and the rich affluent seats on the coast. The smaller Greens party is essentially confined to South East Queensland and the city, and a party called the Bob Katter party only has seats in Northern Queensland. There was another party called one nation, but their vote tanked by an average of 8% in all the areas they had candidates in, with some seats showing 13-15% drops in votes. The leader of this party is knowing for taking huge blows like this, hiding for a few elections then coming back out of the woodwork to try again, but by the time that this could happen, it's likely this leader will be too old to run or dead, and when either of these things happens her party will die and its voters split among the various other parties.

The Katter party is an interesting one. The Labor government has formed a minority government with the Katter party in a previous election when they did not meet the seat threshold for a majority government, but the LNP is also open to working with the Katter Party. The Greens hate it, but they don't really like any party that doesn't have near-identical policies with them. The Katter Party also appeals to voters of almost every other political party in some way, so because of these factors, the Katter Party sits in the extremely favourable position of having both major and many minor parties holding it in an okay view, and having many voters holding the same view. It is for these reasons that the Katter Party looks set to be the Labor parties primary opposition in the future. I would also say that if the Katter Party becomes the primary opposition to the Labor party, the voting system will likely closer resemble a plurality system because of the Katter Party's wide voter appeal.

How about this one?:
RANKED WITHOUT ELIMINATION
Same as instant runoff, but the candidate with the least votes on first choice don't get eliminated. This way, a candidate could win from only second choices if the first choices are very divided.

For example
If Orange and Green are very different, so nobody who votes for Green wants to vote for Orange, and vice versa, but everyone is fine with Purple, Purple would get eliminated in an instant runoff, but in this version, Purple would actually win. This way, nobody would be perfectly happy and nobody would be very angry, but everyone would be content.
To be honest, I don't quite understand why the normal "Instant Runoff" system does eliminate the one with the least votes. After all, as you can see in the video above, the biggest flaw with this system is the elimination.

First choice:
Orange: 50
Green: 50
Purple: 0
Second choice:
Orange: 8
Green: 9
Purple: 83


Of course, if a party gets more than 50% on the first choice, they've won. If nobody gets >50% or if it's a tie, the second votes are added in. If it's still no candidate with >50% voters or if it's a tie, the third votes are added in. If there still is no winner, the voting would have to be redone, or all three candidates could win and cooperate.

Potentially, there could also be a way to vote "I don't want this", which could be a negative vote for whoever you really don't want, so if it was split 50/50 on two candidates and neither is ok with the other, it would count as nobody wanting either of those parties. It wouldn't affect votes too much, other than making it so that heavily disliked candidates are less likley to win than candidates that are just a bit disagreed with.

Let's do a vote to decide what system we will use. We'll do the vote with plurality voting.

33 people want instant runoff. 33 people want approval. 34 want plurality. Plurality wins.

If we used instant runoff, we could remove approval. Instant runoff then get 66 votes to plurality's 34. Instant runoff wins.

Finally, if we used approval, 66 are fine with instant runoff, 67 are fine with approval and 34 are fine with plurality. Approval wins.

@Primer
Actually Switzerland has a system that is very close to approval voting.

We elect politicians for both our chambers of congress with a list. On this list, we write a defined number of candidates, every candidate gets a vote for himself and for his party. It is allowed to write down a candidate's name twice but overall one can't give more votes than the predefined number. The seats in congress are then split up with respect to the ratio of the different votes for each party and they then send their best candidates.
The problem you describe does happen but based on experience this does not give the opposition more votes but just drives the parties into different subjects so that they do not steal from each other. This helps our democracy to always consider all perspectives as ideas that appeal to only a very small voter base can't form coalitions.
In case of elections for a small number of candidates (city mayors or similar) the parties that have similar voter bases speak with each other and then only nominate one candidate that represents both interests.

One method that you didnt mention is called alternative vote, it is similar to instant runoff in which you rank all your options but in alternative vote you don't eliminate parties 1 at a time what you do is let's say there are 3 parties, everyone who votes must put them in order 1, 2 and 3. The party which is put 3rd gets 0 point, 2nd gets 1 point and 1st gets 2 points, then you get the sum of all of the parties points and whoever scores highest wins, the flaw with this system is that it tends to give allot of wins to moderate candidates that no one hates but no one likes.

Here in France, we have a two-round runoff. First, all candidates (11 in 2017, for example) are put against each other. If a candidate has over 50% of all votes, he automatically wins by absolute majority (which, to the best of my knowledge, has never happened). If not, the two highest ranking parties are put in the second round, and the one who gets the majority in that round wins. The two rounds are seperated by a few weeks to give time for extra debates, affiliations...
It's far from flawless, but it's not too awful either.

None of these factions can gain a majority by themselves - the current prime minister's party got 48 mandates out of 175 in the last election and usually getting the majority will require a coalition of 3 or more parties to have the majority. Instant runoff's problem is like hiding Plurality's problems further down the line. And it gets worse the more candidates there are, with extremely unintuitive winners/losers.
Ranked Choice voting is a horrible name for it because that gives the impression it's literally the only voting system that ranks choices. Which just isn't true. There are better ways to rank choices, which avoid accidentally crossing off a popular second-or-so choice early on. They are more complicated in their evaluation but ballot-wise they are identical to IRV.

Approval itself is the best possible system that is as simple as it is. Like, effectively just as simple as Plurality but much more expressive. It does have the problem of, even in the absence of dishonest voters, effectively forcing being overly strategic, since you can't just "partially" approve of a candidate. Hence, some broader Score variant with 5-10 levels would be better still, but it'd certainly sacrifice the rather beautiful simplicity of Approval.

(Socre is also sometimes confused with Borda count though, which is another atrocious system, particularly because it handles dishonest voters so terribly. Score voting is not Borda count, and I think it would be nice if you could make a video explaining those as well.)

I personally prefer the Score varieties. But a proper ranked choice system (i.e. not IRV - perhaps something like Schulze) would also be fine on my book.

First past the post can be confusing as a term, as it technically relates to the total number of seats won in a legislative body, as opposed to the individual seat voting system. Technically any legislative body that requires a majority of seats to form a government is FPTP. Ironically the UK isn't a true FPTP because the monarch (head of state) can choose which party leads the government, and it doesn't have to be the majority party. Other countries or constituent nations such as Germany, Northern Ireland etc require coalitions by design, though some that are designed to be coalition based can sometimes create a majority (NI assembly technically could, but the Scottish Parliament has).

What about STV (Single Transferable Vote)

Let me set a problem: you have 3 electorates, they all voted 66% purple and 34% Green. In a normal election, all 3 seats would be purple.

But what if we merge the electorate into 1 with 3 seats?
Well, you will see that the vote will be distributed to the 3 seats, so 2 seats for purple and 1 for Green.
It's a bit more complicated than that, but i think it would make the central squeeze very unlikely and it will be more representative of the voters, you can have more than 3 as well, like 5, 7, maybe even 538! But that can and will cause more complexities in the system.

I recommend CGP Grey's video on STV.

BTW, The Australian Senate actually use this system.

I wonder in which category germany's system (and that of many other countries probably, but I'm not familiar with those) would fall. Here you can vote (in parliament elections, there are local elections for the individual states, districts and counties also) for one candidate, so a single person that you would like to be in the parliament (direct mandate), this is called the primary vote. Then you have a secondary vote where you vote for one of the parties that are available for election, which is usually quite many. Every winner of the primary vote then gets a seat in the parliament, with the rest of the seats being assigned proportioally to those parties that got at least 5 percent of the votes. Theres a problem with direct mandates as assigning the remaining seats proportionally may be impossible because a party has too many direct mandates, so would be overrepresented, which leads to extra seats being assigned to the other parties to compensate this. This leads to the parliament growing basically every election, because of which germany has one of the biggest parliaments in the world. Nevertheless I think this is a pretty solid system which doesnt suffer the two-party-problem. Example: Results in 2017 were 32.9% CDU/CSU (christian democrats / cristian socials (NOT socialists)), 20.5% SPD (social democrats), 10.7% greens, 9.2% The Left, 12.6% AfD (right)

What if we turn votes into a non-transferable currency you get for being alive? Spend your votes on approving or dissapprovinv candidates, ballot measures, etc. Have a particular area of expertise? Spend them there. Want a law repealed? Spend them on disapproving it. Want to make your own laws? Submit them to a government suggestion box that exists in every town and spend them on approving it, them convince people to spend their precious, finite votes on it. If it stays above some threshold long enough (with going above that threshold triggering the next ballot to be sent out to everyone in the jurisdiction to include that law) then it will become law. Everyone is a legislator with equal say even if people specialize into niche issues. Really really want something to happen? Spend all your votes on it. Prefer one candidate to another but really hate a third? Spend some votes eliminating the candidate you don't like and some votes supporting the one you do.

Hell, make a second non-transferable vote currency that you get for being alive that tells the government how it's budget should work. You get to donate it to any government program and this directly corresponds to a fraction of national GDP spent on that program. Save it, and it lowers taxes or the profit margin of state industry to compensate. If everyone saves it, they can vote in neoliberal austerity. If everyone spends it by donating to the military, they get a war economy. If they spend it on state industry, they get industrial socialism, if they spend it on healthcare, housing, and food aid programs, they get the welfare state.

Within a given organization, this system could be mirrored. Thus, a given organization would pay it's members two non-transferable vote currencies, one for rulemaking and one for budgeting, redeemable only at it, in order for the organization to decide how it's resources are spent and what the rules are of the organization. For organizations with an income that does not come from membership fees or taxation of members, such as a business or a government bureau, this would allow all members of the organization an equal say in the long run. One possibility would be to even make staffing decisions on this basis, essentially allowing unhelpful members to be anonymously voted off the island by those concerned about staffing issues, without handing the keys to the kingdom to either supervisors or day one trainees, but still making everyone equally powerful within the organization in the long run. Even for example promotions could be run as elections where all affected are allowed to spend votes.

If taken to this extent, such a system would allow everyone both more free choice than pretty much anyone has now, and equality beyond what anyone has now. Indeed, if all organizations over a certain size were required to use this manner of decision-making, there could be no extraction of profit that the organization's members did not approve of, and everyone would be a legislator and an equal owner in every organization they were a member of.

Prefer the Norwegian voting rather than American. We have a bunch of different political groups. There's a big one here too like Red and blue. That would make the picture much more honest for the small party's, and they would have much closer chance of getting over the 4% line, and made an importance by atleast having 1 representative out of all those 169.

It's also not one party that rule the government, it's a mixture. It's two big sides that collaborate and include smaller parties to be the majority of the votes, and the bigger the favourite they are on their own, the less they need to include smaller parties.

There's also another big negative effect on our system. Like in our capital, there's a green party, with one focus. Better climate, more green solutions etc. And they are willing to take the side of whoever promises the most green support. 7:45 As an Aussie I feel the need to fact check you a little. The election results you show and claim are the result of our ranked choice voting are a little more complicated then it might seem.

You’ve shown the most recent federal senate (upper house) results, which uses a slightly different version of ranked choice which is honestly super confusing. (Each state gets 12 senators, and each territory gets 2, everyone in that state or territory regardless of their specific electorate votes for the senators from their state directly. We’re usually given a comically large ballot (A2 paper maybe?) with 150ish names of potential senators on it, arranged in their parties. You can vote for the parties you’d prefer, or you can vote for individual senators. You’re given a minimum number of choices you have to provide (usually about 5 for parties, or 12 for individuals), though you are allowed to rank every single party or every single candidate (yes, over 150) if you want to. Then some magic happens, and someone works out how to parse the different inputs and either individuals are directly elected by having received more than 6% of the vote, or parties receive enough of the vote that they’re allowed to allocate X number of senators) For some reason, it is relatively easy for minor parties and independents to pick up seats in the senate

Our Lower House, uses pretty straight forward ranked choice. Each electorate directly votes for who they want to hold their seat. There’s normally 2-9 choices. (2 major parties, LNP and ALP contest every seat, the Greens will generally contest most seats, some seats have several independents, and other minor parties as well). In this set up, it is quite hard for anyone but the two major parties to win seats. Usually out of 150 seats, only 3 or 4 go to someone other than the two major parties, and going back a few years, it was even less common for minor parties to win seats.

TL;DR the promisingly mixed results you claim are the result of ranked choice come from a somewhat arcane mutant sibling of traditional ranked choice voting, our more straight forward use of ranked choice in Australia still normally elects mostly just the two major parties

Edit: the Australian senate probably most closely resembles approval, but it’s still oodles more complicated

Hm, in Germany (where I am) we have a multi-winner system. Basically, the ruling party(s) have to have over 50% approval combined.
Suppose the following results:
Party A: 40%, Party B: 30% Party C: 25% Party D: 5%
After the vote, the parties have to agree on a coalition (collaboration) that hits over 50% This might mean:
- Party A collaborating with Party B
- Party A collaborating with Party C.
or even:
- Party B and C collaborating, and Party A not getting to rule at all despite having the most votes, yet the majority of the people are represented.
The Coalition Forming may take weeks and last time the political parties had such big problems collaborating that almost no coalition could be formed and a revote was almost needed. But just almost.

However, we can only vote for one party. And I'm really curious what you say about the combination of Multi-Winner system plus Approval voting, cause as it stands I see it as the perfect upgrade to our system - Vote for everyone you approve of so all percentages are represented for the coalition forming. As it stands, we have multiple parties I approve of kind of but none that fits my views perfectly (well, one almost but its very small). With a Multi-Vote I could just pick all my views roughly align with and it seems like down the line it would lead to more representative percentages.

In Denmark we have a plurality system that doesnt suck as much as in the US, because the parties themselves "vote" for prime minister, not the people. The people just vote for how many representatives each party should have in the congress, and then the party, or coalition of parties, with the most representatives decide who the prime minister should be (usually the head of the largest party in the coalition). The spoiler effect is still present though, in that new parties need at least 50k votes accross the entire country to get 1 representative, and thus anyone who wants to start a new party need people to believe that they will succeed, though if they dont exceed that threshold, then the party decides who the votes go to then (so they are not wasted votes).

In italy we have Plurality system, but with some boundaries.
In order:
-A voter can only vote for a party and/or a candidate (still, with a total of 1 party in total involved in the vote)
-A party, to become the Majority leader, should have at least 40% of the popular vote
-A party, to enter the parliament or the senate (here we vote for both, during the same election, but votes can be different and only who is over 25 can vote for the senate) should at least get 3% of popular vote, if not, the votes of the party are divided equally between all parties
The problem is that hardly ever a single party (or Arranges of parties, like the Left-wing or Right-Wing group) reaches 40%, so, in order to create a government, the Party/Group with the most votes have to form a Coalition with a party/group that let it reach the said 40%, wich will lead to:
1. Delays in the form of the government.
2. Instability between the two parts.
3. Friction between the two parts and subsequent inadequate follow of any of the stated government plan
4. Inconsistency of the government plan
5. A collapse of the government
Also, this system discourages from voting the small parties, that have maybe a really good govern schedule, but will strive to reach the 3%, nullifying the votes of electors, which is a bit unconstitutional.

What do you think of systems that trace resistance instead?
Instead of choosing the candidate you would like to win the most you'd give each candidate a "dislike score" - and the one having the lowest dislike score would win.

One method we use much at work to make decisions is called "systemic consensus". Each participant gives each option a score from 0 ("I'd be fine with that option") to 10 ("I absolutetly dislike this option and would not support it!"). Winner of this system is not the candidate with the greatest fan base, it is instead the one who's most accepted and would face the lowest resistance. Systemic Consensus has some further rules but they wouldn't fit into an election.

I think it could be really good especially for two party systems if done correctly since those systems often have people who like one option but hate the other.

This system may fix the chicken dilemma of Approval Rating because each person can just honestly enter the resistance into a scale and your honest vote is the strategic one.

6:50 center squeezing is not a problem with the voters but with the positioning of the parties. The example in the video does not hold water. In a two party country both parties will position themselves as near to the center as possible with one party slightly to the right and one slightly to the left. The scenario orange green would never happen. When you have three parties, one will position itself directly center but the other two will still try to go as center as they can. They will not be as center as in a two party system, but they will still squeeze the third party to as few votes as possible.

Voting systems are neat and all but I've always felt (and this is an opinion, not science) that media has a far greater impact on election outcomes than the voting system ever does.

Australia is extremely 2 party, you can point at the small niche parties as evidence we aren't 2 party, but only the greens have any real chance of making a proper government (it'll never happen, but they do have enough candidates country wide to actually fill a majority), greens tend to fold into the Labor party after the election, though I would say they are the most independent party we have.

On the other hand, the other small parties that get 1 or 2 seats tops are usually extremist versions of the (Right Wing) Liberal party, they look independent on paper, but at the end of the day they work so closely with the Liberals and have such a similar agenda that they are basically just Liberal party members.

I'm not an expert on political history even in my own country, so I'm not sure how we got here, but I believe (again, opinion) that the reactionary tendencies of humans and the tribalistic nature of 'us vs them' are so inherent in human psychology that unfortunately 2 party systems seem to be a product of our psychology more than our voting system. To roll back to my first point on media, you can't model a voting population as rational because media influence (and other factors like colleagues, family, etc) will often sway a voter to vote entirely irrationally.

I know many many cases of people who continue to vote for parties that actively work to harm them, and until I start seeing people voting for their own best interests I refuse to believe that voters are rational. Until voters are rational, game theory and modelling just aren't useful tools to model elections, and studying them won't give us a system that 'fixes society', the only way to improve our society under democracy is for voters to vote rationally and with perfect information. I can't see that happening.

What if we had a run-off voting where you could vote against one, single candidate you didn't like? 🤔

Take the scenario from this video for instance, 3 candidates, 3 slots, where you have your first and second choices with a different slot for a "negative" vote where it subtracts a vote from the candidate in that slot.

So, say your 1st choice was P, second choice was O and you didn't like G. And G voters didn't like purple. Leaving, in the end, I in a commanding lead followed by a small pool of votes for P and little to no votes left for G.

I think this would result in compromises a lot more often and highly favor under dogs as well as incentivise more candidates to run because you would only be able to vote against 1 candidate (if you wanted, it wouldn't be mandatory) no matter how many people were running. This could go for primaries and general elections. Would it be useful? You could only vote against a single candidate but you could vot for as many as we're available in defending order of desireablility and even leave spaces blank if, say, there were like 7 candidates but you only wanted to vote for like 3 and you had one you wanted to vote against.

In this system I'm proposing P might get the most 1st choice picks but almost all G's would vote against P and vice versa for P against G. Resulting in a landslide for O but that also means that O is the most agreeable and this would solve the problem of pushing the middle out, wouldn't it? Not to mention this would incentivise more people to run because, again, only 1 slot per ballot is a negative vote and it would only be used if there was someone you DEFINITELY didn't want in office. Would this be useful? It's seems like it to me, more choices is better when it comes to voting and rank choice handles many candidates (even for just a single position) well.

I think it solves the issue middle squeeze issue by allowing for the opposite. Does it have any non-obvious down sides, though? 🤔

The important feature of this type of voting is that there's only one winner in the election. Many democracies have parliaments where the parties compete over seats and the votes are counted against how many seats they amount to. Countries that have many parties usually have this type of system.

While in US, one winner is selected in many elections, then the amount of seats are the sum the amount of elections they've "won". That's how you get two party systems. It also seems that these solutions are made for that type of system in mind or where there can only be 1 candidate winner (maybe like a president?).

However, voting can still be very strategic even in my first example. Popular parties can decide that a minimum amount of seats have to be present to be eligible for any seats, so even if a party has earned a seat, they still might be barred because they haven't earned an arbitrary number of seats (like 4 or 8 for example). Then the votes of the party that was prevented to take part in politics is divided between the parties that are left. This means that new parties need quite a lot of support to be eligible for participating in politics, meaning that voters who have niche preferences have to be strategic or are just throwing their votes away.

ok so hear me out: you do the ranking system for voting (which is where you rank all of the candidates from your favorite in first place, to your least favorite in last place), and the scoring is similar to golf. if you put candidate A as your first choice, candidate B as your second choice, and candidate C as your third choice, it gives candidate A one point, candidate B two points, and candidate C three points, and so on. This helps to reduce the center squeeze/spoiler effect, if not completely nullify the effect by pitting every candidate against each other at once, versus the instant runoff voting's method of eliminating one candidate at a time. this is, of course, assuming that no one leaves a blank space on their ballot, but this can be assured with something as simple as a google form where one answer for each position is required before it is turned in. we could also maybe allow ties if someone is not sure which of two candidates they like more. I am wondering why no country has taken this approach, and am wondering if I skipped over any vital piece of information that makes this method bad.

The so-called "flaw" of the instant runoff election is definitely an intended consequence and does not demonstrably lead to more radical candidates winning. Sure, the more moderate purple voters do not end up with their preferred choice, but that was just in one single election. If the moderate candidate finds that enough voters prefer the more radical positions in either direction, the moderate candidate adjusts their position towards either wing over time and can end up taking back a majority of votes from just the centre. In the end, it wasn't that the compromise offered by yellow was the most optimal compromise just because it had the highest average preference, rather a lack of voters in yellow's core base area indicated a societal desire for a decisive resolution of this policy.

It's interesting in this model that approval is based on a shared-range proximity to each candidate, although I do believe it's a necessary result of the spatial reduction to two dimensions. That said, it creates a generalization issue with the way that "betrayals" are presented. A reduced dimension that dictates approval-disapproval may be irrelevant population-wise, but especially salient to a given voter (or subset of voters). As a result, candidates that appear close in the reduced voter space may have a salient difference which taints the candidate and leads these otherwise close voters to disapprove despite proximity in a manner that is a "betrayal" despite being honest to the voter's beliefs. I wonder if there would be a realistic way of accounting for these sparse controversial dimensions that single-issue voters cling onto thus influencing elections, perhaps some sort of +/- attribute assigned to voters based on the polarity and magnitude of the issues relevance to the voter (though, this would depend on a greater understanding of the distribution of salience voters assign to the various dimensions of variation among candidates, something I don't think a party-representing model would be able to easily parse out due to parties issue-conglomerating tendency.) That said, all of this would needlessly complicate this as an explanatory tool. Nonetheless a fun idea to think through for me :)

At 7:44, you show the Senate, which uses Single Transferable Vote, while the House of Representatives (HoR) uses IRV, and the House crossbench has never begun a term numbering more than six MPs since the 1930s, (and even that is drawing a long bow).

6:40 Simplifying this down to just the purple voters seems slightly deceptive. Yes, the blobs who put purple first would have preferred for orange to win, but if the board had been distributed slightly differently then purple would have won and the green-first voters would have been unhappy. The decision was made by which candidate the majority of the orange-first voters disliked least.

This is the fundamental result of IRV. In this case, once the third-place candidate is eliminated the overall result is simply a majority vote between the other two—the same result you would get from a plurality vote between purple and green. With only three candidates this described "center-squeeze" is actually a preferable outcome, but when you scale up and add more candidates the reality is that ranked voting rapidly breaks down. The candidates who are unable to garner large support are eliminated, and the process continues until you hit the lowest common denominator: not the candidate the most people like, but the candidate the least people hate. And this makes every voter who didn't place the LCD candidate first unhappy with the result.
