Sadly, Instant-Runoff Voting doesn't really address the core problems of FPTP, and this can be visualized too. More people need to be wary of the over-promises of IRV that's being done by its promoters. Unfortunately, this visualization here wasn't very good in this regard. If you guys want a more detailed explanation let me know and I'll write something more in-depth, but the basics is this:

A ranked preference between A and B is a binary classification. It draws a line between A and B and forces everyone to take sides. Crucially, it is the candidates who end up drawing the line, not the voters, so all ranked systems (not just IRV) work in terms of "forcefully splitting the group into two maximally-competing factions". Approval voting and other cardinal methods do not suffer from this problem, as nobody has to "take sides" on anything.

The logic behind IRV, with its transfers until a majority preference appears, assumes there are only two big factions A and B competing in an election, and that they have an hierarchical structure with many subfactions (A1, A2..., B1, B2, ... etc.), where each subfaction is a candidate. The goal of IRV is to dismiss this internal structure and let the "battle" between the two big factions proceeded unimpeded. It's a system solely intended to prevent the structure within two competing groups from changing the winner. But it HAS to assume there are two groups, and only two groups.

In order for IRV to work and make sense, these factions A and B can never have any overlap, not a single voter. This means everyone votes (some order of A/B) > (some order of B/A). If a SINGLE voter votes, say A1 > B1 > A2, then you can have all the pathologies of the system appearing.

This mechanics of "two big factions" A vs B renders all other ideological structure largely irrelevant, as the entire space collapses into a 1-dimensional axis defined by A and B, NOT the ideological distribution of voters. You end up with a two faction/coalition system, even if you have more parties. The parties become symbolic. The dominating voices in the A and B factions then get to split the electorate however they see fit, and this is how you get a bunch of political issues correlated, lack of options and stagnation. IRV will just hide the problem under the carpet, as it has done historically everywhere it has been implemented. It's a voting method mechanics improvement over FPTP, but it's not a political improvement. The main problem of FPTP isn't the spoiled elections, but the ideological collapse into two big factions. IRV completely internalizes that problem.

The way out of this is to adopt a voting system that is not factionalist, but instead consensus-driven. Of the ranked systems, Condorcet methods do this best. They work by finding the most significant "A vs B" faction split among all possible pairwise matches between candidates. A candidate who wins every pairwise matchup is the Condorcet winner, and they are in a sense the faction closest to the "ideological consensus".

The systems that are consensus-driven and don't impose any faction structure are approval voting, STAR voting, score voting and other cardinal methods. They don't work by forcing people take sides. Candidates don't get to "draw the line" to split the ideological space however they see fit. Candidates win when they are the most representative of the consensus on issues. (This has nothing to do with centrism/moderates, because the ideological space is not one-dimensional. If there are multiple polarizing and multiple consensus issues, the notion of a "centrist" doesn't make sense. A centrist is a fringe position in such a scenario.)

These cardinal (and the Condorcet) methods would radically address the main issues we have we politics and democracy worldwide, on a deeper and much more important way. We desperately need to move away from factionalist methods like FPTP , top-two runoffs and IRV, as well as changing the similarly-motivated decision processes we have adopted everywhere in our societies.

Generally an informative video but very wrong analysis on Australia's 'two-party' dominance being the result of the centre-squeeze effect.

The centre-squeeze effect requires 3 parties to be in the running to win. In the majority of Australian electorates, whether federal, state or territorial, the election result is still dominated by two parties. The centre-squeeze phenomenon does occur in some electorates where the Greens, KAP, SA-BEST, or One Nation are running but no, Australia's 'two-party' dominance is not a result of centre-squeeze.

Also, you may have noticed I've been writing 'two-party'. Because Australia actually does have 3 major parties (if you don't live in QLD): Labor, Liberal and National. It's just that Liberal and National typically form a coalition to form government, but they often run candidates against each other in rural seats around the country. I mean the NSW Nationals threatened to break that coalition with the NSW Liberals this year. They are different parties, hence 3 (or 4 if you count the Greens) major parties.

That's not to say instant runoff doesn't have it's problems in real applications, but they mostly come from using it to elect single members not from centre-squeeze. The Greens often get double, around 10%, the first preference votes that the Nationals get, yet they only have 1 seats whereas the Nationals have 10. The issue comes from the concentration of Nationals voters in rural areas and the spread of Greens voters around the country.

Also 7:44 is picture of the Senate election results, which follows the STV system, not instant runoff. Kind of disappointing the amount of effort you put into this video. I'm not trying to be nit-picky; it's just the information presented in that 8-second segment is plain wrong.

Honestly single winner voting is just bad in general. No matter how you do it, you can wind up in situations where at least the tiniest fraction less than half of the population aren't represented in the government because of the outcome. That's honestly not good, and it can allow for the policies of a slim majority or in some cases not even a majority (depending on the voting system) to be put in place, which could be against or not addressing the concerns of those who lost. At the absolute worst this could encourage discrimination against a minority if the slim majority prefers it or benefits from it, and in some cases less than that.

Of course, the ability for political parties to adjust their position over time to better fit the nash equilibrium which inevitable arises from these types of voting systems helps, as well as doing something like the American Senate or House of Representatives where a lot of different positions are filled by votes helps remedy some of these problems. You really only get serious problems when the position you're voting for has a lot of individual power, for example the American Presidency.

Basically whatever voting system exists needs to take into account the needs of everyone and give them all appropriate representation, and seek to reach a far greater than 50% agreement or at least a compromise rather than just have whichever political party happens to have a slim majority make the laws for a time. Which is really difficult to create actually.

Here is my method (feel free to find the flaws in the replies):

Each voter can give a score from 0 to 1 (with decimals) to each candidate. The total scores given has to add up to 1 per voter. This works well because each voter essentially has one "vote" but can divide that vote among each candidate. You can do a blob simulation by having each blob divide their vote based on each candidate's distance to the blob on the graph. Removing and adding candidates won't have too much of an effect as voters will just increase and decrease the score for each candidate proportionally. To me, it seems really ideal in theory but IDK if it works in practice.

Hey, what about the German voting system?
The simplified version goes like this: everyone votes for a party and the party gets the proportional amount of seats in the parliament (if above the 5%-threshold). Then the leaders of each parliament fraction talk to each other trying to form a coalition with 50%+ of all parliament seats. Only then the chancellor will be elected by the parliament.

Of course in reality there is a little more to it than this, but overall it works quite well!

I designed a better system many years ago, called the policy vote. It works similar to the runoff voting, but you are only voting policies, not candidates. This is how it works:

1. candidates choose what policies they would like to enact/reverse
2. all policies are placed in a full list and first handed to all candidates, at which point those candidates will choose their position officially as a vote card (which also includes other candidate positions)
3. the population votes based on what position they hold on each policy (whether they approve of it happening or disapprove)
4. each policy that receives at least 51% approval will be considered 1 point, the candidate with the most points wins
5. only the policies that were given at least 75% approval will be allowed an attempt of enactment/reversal as stated by the policy outline....going after any policy that does not meet that criteria will result in immediate action for dismissal/impeachment.
6. any new policies that were not part of the election cycle will have to be done through congress

What if, instead of immediately eliminating the least popular candidate in Instant Runoff, we instead put every possible pairing of candidates against each other. For the example used in the video, the pairings would be:

Orange v Green
Green v Purple
Orange v Purple

For each pairing, we would be able to ignore the 3rd candidate and look at who the winner would be if the colors in the pairing were the only ones running. If we do this, we would reach the following results:

Orange v Green = Orange
Green v Purple = Green
Orange v Purple = Orange

From these pairings, we can easily see that, in an election between two candidates, purple can never win. Therefore, we can safely eliminate purple from the election. Now, we have only two candidates, and we can use the pairing that we came up with earlier to determine a winner:

Orange v Green = Orange

Hooray! We were able to eliminate the Center-squeeze phenomenon with a modified version of instant runoff. If you find a potential flaw, like the ones shown in the video, please describe it so that we can come up with a solution.

I wonder if you could combine them all, I present to you the tier system:
In case of there being 3 voting candidates, each voter receives the opportunity to submit 4 votes: Vote A (Equivalent to 3 voting points), Vote B (Equivalent to 2 voting points), and Vote C (Equivalent to 1 voting point). In the case of 4 options or more, a new voting rank (Vote D) would be added, and so on. An extra option of not giving any voting points is also granted by not submitting a vote rank for the candidate you don't want to approve.
All of the votes are counted as voting points, and after the first electoral round, whatever option/candidate has the least points gets disqualified. In case of a tie taking place, the party with the most A Votes will be victorious over the other (If there's a tie with A Votes, then B, then C). Then a second electoral round is hosted with the remaining candidates/options and the process repeats until only one comes out victorious.

Nice video Primer! Just 1 thing that bothers me about it, that i think would expand on your explanation:

Every single voting system has the range of what a person is willing to vote for, their range of tolerance for the policies on the axis. The difference between the voting systems would then be:
Plurality: Vote for the closest candidate within your tolerance.
Instant runoff: Rank the candidates within your tolerance (leaving out any other candidates, indicating that any candidate outside your tolerance is equally unacceptable).
Approval: Vote for every candidate within your tolerance.

I think this would better illuminate the "center squeeze" argument, as it has been used in american politics to tell the Left (e.g. Sanders voters) that electing the Left candidate would only cause the Right to win, because the Center candidate would pull voters away from the Right, and get ALL the votes from the Left. The video doesn't really show how moving to the center causes the furthest Left voters to be disenfranchised, because either candidate is outside of their tolerance level, causing them to not vote at all.

Would love to see more videos on this topic, and perhaps see you play around with the parameters for the tolerances like you did with the social distancing simulation video :)

Yeah, Instant Runoff is probably the most popular alternative voting system today, but a lot of voting reformers have issues with it, with some believing that it ultimately won't change anything vs Plurality. For example the UK and Canada are both more multi-party than Australia's lower house, even though the UK and Canada use Plurality and Australia's lower house uses IRV. It makes it so tiny parties can't be spoilers, but it still doesn't allow any sort of thriving multiparty system, and almost every method behaves the same as Plurality when there are only two strong options.

The chicken dilemma is probably the worst-case scenario for Approval, though it may be worth pointing out that, unlike with the Prisoner's Dilemma, mutual betrayal is not the Nash equilibrium, so compromising is somewhat encouraged. Score could encourage it more by allowing voters to hedge their bets, and STAR should improve it even more if necessary (though that one might come with a small cost)

Instant runoff can be used in cases where you need multiple winners. You just set the "win" requirement to be > 1/(n+1) %. So, in a single winner case, that winner needs 50% + 1 to be considered the winner, else you drop the lowest candidate and retally the votes. For 2 winners, you need 1/(2+1) or > 33% to be a winner. This works as the sum of the two winners doesn't leave enough for the third person to be above the threshold.
So, school boards and corporate commissioners and other groups can all use the Instant Runoff as can elections such as House of Representatives or Senators.

For added complications, some countries elect their leaders in different ways. The US directly votes for their president, Canada however picks their PM indirectly by voting for local representatives. Changing the voting system of a country delegitimizes the prior elections within that country, as well as delegitimizes the election with the new voting system. Prior elections will be seen as invalid, because the replaced voting system will be ruled "bad" while the new system will be doubted by the status quo. It doesn't matter if an election was objectively fair or not. If there is doubt in the electoral system, then the people will not accept the election and the stability of the nation-state will be at risk.
